The energy stored in a capacitor is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒE = Â½ C VÂ².

With V = 200 volts, this energy is

â€ƒâ€ƒE = Â½ (4Ã—10â»â¶ F) (200Â²)

â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= (0.16)/2
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= 0.08 Joules.

Next, consider the discharge path. The copper wire is 5 mm long (0.005 m) and has a resistance of 4 Î©/m. Hence, its resistance is

â€ƒâ€ƒR = 4 Î©/m Ã— 0.005 m = 0.02 Î©.

At the instant of discharge (assuming the full 200 V appears across the wire), the initial current would be

â€ƒâ€ƒI = V / R = 200 V / 0.02 Î© = 10,000 A.

Even though this current is enormous, the energy delivered is only 0.08â€‰J, and it is dissipated in an extremely short time (the RC time constant is Ï„ = R C_total = 0.02 Î© Ã— 4Ã—10â»â¶ F = 8Ã—10â»â¸ s).

Now, to see if this energy could melt the wire, we estimate the temperature rise in the short piece of wire. The mass per meter of wire is given as 0.045 g/m. Thus, the mass of a 5 mm length is

â€ƒâ€ƒm = 0.045 g/m Ã— 0.005 m = 0.000225 g 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= 2.25Ã—10â»â· kg.

The heat energy required to raise the temperature is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ”T = E / (m c)

where c is the specific heat capacity of copper (approximately 385 J/(kgÂ·K)). Substituting in,

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ”T = 0.08 J / (2.25Ã—10â»â· kg Ã— 385 J/(kgÂ·K))
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ‰ˆ 0.08 / (8.6625Ã—10â»âµ)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ‰ˆ 922 K.

This represents the temperature rise above room temperature. Even if we assume a starting temperature of about 20Â°C (293 K), the final temperature would be roughly

â€ƒâ€ƒ293 K + 922 K â‰ˆ 1215 K.

However, note that the melting point of copper is about 1358 K (1085Â°C). In addition, not all energy may be perfectly deposited into the wire; some may be lost to other parts of the circuit and through radiation. Moreover, the energy is distributed over the entire discharge curve, and thermal conduction along the wire can further mitigate the local temperature rise.

Thus, despite the very high peak current, the extremely low total stored energy (0.08 J) is insufficient to raise the temperature of the 5 mm length of copper wire to its melting point.

\[

â€ƒâ€ƒB = â€“Eâ‚€.
Next, the sphereâ€™s surface (r = a) must be an equipotential (with no Î¸â€“dependence). That is, we require that

We wish to know how an isolated, finite conductor that (by some preparation) carries a uniform volume charge density Ï will evolve when it is an ohmic (conducting) medium of conductivity Ïƒ. In any conductor the charges will eventually rearrange themselves so that the static equilibrium has no electric field inside the conductor (and hence no current), with all free charges â€œpiled upâ€ on the surface (in general, with a nonâ€uniform surface distribution if the body is not spherical). However, how that rearrangement (â€œrelaxationâ€) takes place â€“ and how the stored energy decreases â€“ depends on the geometry.

Letâ€™s analyze the two cases in detail.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
1. General Considerations

Because the conductor is ohmic, the conduction current obeys Ohmâ€™s law (in differential form)
â€ƒâ€ƒJ = ÏƒE.
Along with Gaussâ€™s law and the continuity equation,
â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Â·J = âˆ’âˆ‚Ï/âˆ‚t,
this leads (in what is called the â€œcharge relaxationâ€ problem) to a decay of charges on a time scale of order
â€ƒâ€ƒÏ„ ~ Îµ/Ïƒ,
where Îµ is the (local) dielectric constant. In many textbooks (for example, when the conductor is â€œmacroscopicâ€ and the fields vary slowly) one finds that the â€œrelaxation timeâ€ for a pure monopole perturbation is exactly Ï„ = Îµ/Ïƒ.

However, the particular way in which the charge distribution â€œdecaysâ€ â€“ i.e. how the various parts of the initially â€œnonâ€equilibriumâ€ charge density rearrange â€“ depends on the symmetry of the body. In all cases the energy initially stored in the electric fields is reduced, with the difference being dissipated via Joule heating (and perhaps even radiation if the timeâ€“variation of the current is sufficiently rapid, although that is usually negligible in the quasiâ€“static limit).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
2. (a) The Spherical Conductor

Imagine a finite, perfectly conducting sphere (radius R) in which, by some means, the free charge is uniformly distributed throughout the volume. (Note that such a condition is not an electrostatic equilibrium; in electrostatics the free charges would reside at the surface so that the interior Eâ€field would vanish.) Because the sphere is symmetric, the solution of Maxwellâ€™s equations â€“ namely, of the Laplace/Poisson problem â€“ must also be spherically symmetric.

Thus, the electric field inside the sphere will be purely radial. (Recall that for a uniformly charged sphere one finds E(r) âˆ r if the charge were â€œfrozenâ€ in and not allowed to move.) But here the field drives a conduction current given by

â€ƒâ€ƒJ(r,t) = ÏƒE(r,t).

Since the symmetry is perfect, there is no source of any multipole moment besides the uniform (monopole) one. In fact one may show that the charge density decays exponentially in time according to

â€ƒâ€ƒÏ(t) = Ï(0) e^(â€“t/Ï„)
â€ƒâ€ƒwithâ€ƒÏ„ = Îµ/Ïƒ.
Likewise, the interior electric field decays as E(t) = E(0) e^(â€“t/Ï„).

The final state is reached when the interior field has died away and all remaining net charge has been driven to the surface where it arranges itself uniformly (because of the symmetry) so as to produce a vanishingly small electric field inside. The energy originally stored in the â€œvolumeâ€distributedâ€ field is partly â€œlostâ€ in the sense that the final (electrostatic) energy stored in the surfaceâ€“charge configuration is lower. The energy difference

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ”U = U_initial âˆ’ U_final

has been converted into heat (Joule dissipation) in the conductor during the rearrangement.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
3. (b) The Nonâ€“Spherical Conductor

Now suppose that the conductor has a shape which is not spherically symmetric. Although we again begin with a uniform charge density Ï in the volume, the geometry no longer â€œforcesâ€ the field lines to be radial, and the â€œequipotentialâ€ surfaces in the conductor are not simply concentric spheres. In a conductor at static equilibrium the electric potential must be constant throughout the interior. (Recall that if there were any potential differences there would be currents, by Ohmâ€™s law.) In a nonâ€“spherical object the only possible static charge distribution that leads to no interior electric fields is one in which the charges have moved to the surface and distributed themselves nonâ€“uniformly (in a way that depends on the geometry) so that the entire interior is at the same potential.

As a consequence, the initial uniform volume charge density must â€œdecomposeâ€ into its various multipole components. Although the overall (monopole) charge is still conserved and its associated â€œmodeâ€ decays with the same time constant Ï„ = Îµ/Ïƒ, the nonâ€“monopolar (multipole) parts of the distribution (for example, dipole, quadrupole, etc.) are not â€œnaturalâ€ modes of the final equilibrium state and they decay much faster (with rates determined by the eigenvalues of the Laplace operator in the given geometry). In other words, the evolution generally proceeds in two stages:
â€ƒ(a) A rapid â€œsmoothingâ€ stage during which the nonâ€“monopole (higherâ€“order) parts are rapidly dissipated by internal currents.
â€ƒ(b) A slower decay of the remaining uniform (monopole) component with time constant Ï„ = Îµ/Ïƒ.

The result is that during the relaxation of a nonâ€“spherical conductor the local currents and fields are more complex, and the initial â€œexcessâ€ energy is partly dissipated more quickly as Joule heat associated with the rapid decay of the higher multipole moments. In the final state the free charges have reached the surface and are arranged in a nonâ€“uniform way (because, for a nonâ€“spherical conductor, the equilibrium surface charge density is in general nonâ€“uniform) so that the interior remains an equipotential. Again, the difference between the initial energy stored in the volume distribution and the final (lower) electrostatic energy is dissipated as heat.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
4. Summary of the Energy Evolution

In both cases the eventual equilibrium is one in which the interior of the conductor is fieldâ€“free and the net charge resides on the surface. However, in the spherical case the special symmetry forces the decay to occur in a â€œsingleâ€ mode with all quantities decaying exponentially with the relaxation time Ï„ = Îµ/Ïƒ. In the nonâ€“spherical case the initial uniform density â€œcontainsâ€ nonâ€“equilibrium multipole components that decay on faster time scales (with the monopole decaying as e^(â€“t/Ï„) only after the higher modes have been quickly â€œwashed outâ€). In both cases the energy difference between the initial electric field energy and the final (lower) equilibrium energy is dissipated as Joule heating in the conductor (and, in principle, there may be some â€œlossâ€ to radiation if the transients are sufficiently rapid).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
5. Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)\quad For a spherical conductor:} \quad &\text{The symmetry guarantees that an initially uniform charge density relaxes solely via the}\\
&\text{monopole (spherically symmetric) mode with an exponential decay } \rho(t)=\rho(0)e^{-t/(\epsilon/\sigma)}.\\[1mm]
&\text{Thus, the interior field and current decay as } E(t)=E(0)e^{-t/(\epsilon/\sigma)}, \\
&\text{and in equilibrium all the charge resides uniformly on the surface.}\\[2mm]
\text{(b)\quad For a non--spherical conductor:} \quad &\text{The uniform initial charge density does not match the equilibrium condition (zero interior Eâ€“field)}\\
&\text{for a nonâ€“spherical shape. Its decomposition into multipole components causes the nonâ€“monopole }\\
&\text{modes (dipole, quadrupole, etc.) to decay rapidly while the monopole decays with the same }\\
&\text{timeâ€“constant } \tau=\epsilon/\sigma. \text{ In the final equilibrium the charge is redistributed (nonâ€“uniformly)}\\
&\text{on the surface so that the interior is at constant potential.}\\[1mm]
&\text{In both cases, however, the decrease in the stored electrostatic energy (from the higher energy}\\
&\text{of the initial volume distribution to the lower energy of the final surfaceâ€“charge state) is converted}\\
&\text{to Joule heat during the relaxation.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to solve Maxwellâ€™s equations for a planeâ€polarized field incident normally on a halfâ€space. In the material the field has the \(z\)â€“dependence implied by its propagation â€œintoâ€ the material. (For simplicity we assume no spatial dispersion.) In what follows we indicate a possible derivation for each case.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Step (1). The Wave Equation in the Medium

A plane wave field of the form 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(E=E_{y}(z,t)\,\hat{y}\)
satisfies (with no free charges)
â€ƒâ€ƒ\nabla \times \nabla \times E = -\mu\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\Bigl(\sigma E+\epsilon\frac{\partial E}{\partial t}\Bigr)\,.
Using the vector identity and assuming a \(z\)â€“dependence only, the waveâ€“equation becomes 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\frac{d^2E}{dz^2} = \mu\Bigl(\epsilon + \frac{i\sigma}{\omega}\Bigr)(- \omega^2)E\).
Thus, if we take the oscillatory time dependence \(\exp(-i\omega t)\), we have
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\frac{d^2E}{dz^2} + k^2E= 0\)
with the dispersion relation
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k^2 = \omega^2\mu\Bigl(\epsilon+\frac{i\sigma}{\omega}\Bigr)=\mu\left ( \epsilon\omega^2 + i\omega\sigma \right ).\)

A general solution is 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,e^{ikz-i\omega t}.\)
The different limits for \(\sigma\) lead to different forms for \(k\).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
(a) Large, Real Conductivity (Metal at Low Frequencies)

Here we assume that the conductivity is large; i.e. \(\sigma \gg \omega\epsilon\). Then
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k^2\approx i\omega\mu\sigma.\)

Let us write 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k = \sqrt{i\omega\mu\sigma}\,.\)
Recall that
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\sqrt{i}=\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\),
so
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k = \frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\,\sqrt{\omega\mu\sigma}.\)

Defining the skinâ€depth
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega\mu\sigma}},\)
we can write
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k = \frac{1+i}{\delta}\).

Thus, the field in the metal becomes
â€ƒâ€ƒ
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl[i\frac{1+i}{\delta} z-i\omega t\Bigr]\)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ\(=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr].\)

In words, the wave decays exponentially inside the metal (the skin effect) and has a phase shift proportional to \(z\).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
(b) Dilute Plasmaâ€”Inertiaâ€Limited Conductivity

For a dilute plasma the conductivity is not due to scattering but rather stems from the electron inertia. One is given
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\sigma=i\,\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\).

Then the effective permittivity in the material is
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon+\frac{i\sigma}{\omega} = \epsilon + \frac{i}{\omega}\Bigl(i\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\Bigr)= \epsilon-\frac{ne^2}{m\omega^2}\,.\)

Thus the dispersion relation becomes
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k^2=\omega^2\mu\epsilon_{\rm eff} = \omega^2\mu\Bigl[\epsilon-\frac{ne^2}{m\omega^2}\Bigr].\)

Defining the plasma frequency by
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m}\)â€ƒ (if one works in units where the background permittivity is 1, or more generally one has \(\omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m\epsilon}\) if one wishes to keep track of \(\epsilon\); here we absorb constants as appropriate),
the wave number is
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(k=\omega\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\Bigr)}=\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}.\)

The field inside the plasma is then simply
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl[i\,kz-i\omega t\Bigr]\)
with the \(k\) given above. Notice that when \(\omega<\omega_p\) the expression under the square root becomes negative and the wave is evanescent, while for \(\omega>\omega_p\) the wave propagates with reduced speed.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
(c) Comments on the Optical Properties of Metals in the Ultraviolet

At low frequencies (as in (a)) real high conductivity leads to a complex \(k\) with nearly equal real and imaginary parts; the exponential decay (skin effect) is rapid, and the metal is highly reflective. In a dilute plasma (b) we see that the response becomes â€œinertialâ€: the effective dielectric constant is of the form 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\).
For many metals the plasma frequency \(\omega_p\) is in the ultraviolet. In other words, at frequencies below \(\omega_p\) the response is metallic (highly reflective) while for \(\omega>\omega_p\) the effective permittivity becomes positive and the metal becomes transparent. Thus, in the ultraviolet the optical properties of typical metals change dramatically: they no longer reflect nearly all the incident light but can transmit it. This is why, for example, many metals have a â€œplasma edgeâ€ in their optical spectra.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Final Answers

(a) For a good conductor (large real Ïƒ):
â€ƒâ€ƒ\[
E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \text{with}\quad \delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega\mu\sigma}}.
\]

(b) For a dilute plasma with 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\sigma=i\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\):
â€ƒâ€ƒ\[
E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl[i\,\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}\,z-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad\text{where}\quad \omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m}\,.
\]

(c) In metals the low frequency response (with large Ïƒ) leads to very short skin depths and thus high reflectivity. However in the ultraviolet â€“ where the electron motion is inertiaâ€dominated and the dielectric function becomes 
â€ƒâ€ƒ\(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\) â€“ once \(\omega\) exceeds the plasma frequency the metal becomes transparent.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega \mu \sigma}},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl[i\,\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}\,z-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \omega_p^2=\frac{n e^2}{m},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}&\quad \text{For } \omega<\omega_p \text{ (visible and lower frequencies) metals are strongly reflective (short skin depth), while for } \omega>\omega_p \text{ (in the UV) the effective } \epsilon \text{ is positive and the metal becomes transparent.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

(Also, we assume that the dimensionless quantity (Î³Ï‰/c) â‰ª 1 so that squareâ€root expansions are allowed.) Our goal is twoâ€“fold:

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. Constitutive Relations and Maxwellâ€™s Equations

For a plane wave propagating in the +z direction we assume an electric field of the form

â€ƒâ€ƒE(r, t) = Eâ‚€ exp[i(kz â€“ Ï‰t)],â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(3)

with wave number k (to be determined) and with Eâ‚€ lying in the xyâ€“plane (so that âˆ‡Â·E = 0).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—E = â€“âˆ‚B/âˆ‚tâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(4)
â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—B = Î¼â‚€ âˆ‚D/âˆ‚t.â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(5)

It turns out that the extra term in (2) will lead to a slight â€œmixingâ€ between E and its curl. â€ƒâ€ƒEâ‚‹ = Eâ‚€ (xÌ‚ â€“ i yÌ‚) e^(i(kâ‚‹z â€“ Ï‰t)).â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(5a)

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—E = i k (zÌ‚Ã—E).
A quick computation shows:
â€ƒâ€ƒzÌ‚Ã—(xÌ‚ Â± i yÌ‚) = Â± i (xÌ‚ Â± i yÌ‚).

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—Eâ‚Š = + k Eâ‚Šâ€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—Eâ‚‹ = â€“ k Eâ‚‹,â€ƒâ€ƒ(6)

We start by considering a coaxial structure where the inner conductor has a radius a, the outer conductor has a radius b, and the length of the coaxial region is l (with l â‰« b). The region between the conductors is filled with a dielectric that has both a permittivity Îµ and a conductivity Ïƒ. We need to calculate two things:

1. The resistance between the center (inner) conductor and the coaxial (outer) conductor.
2. The capacitance between the inner and outer conductors.

Because the dielectric is slightly conductive (with conductivity Ïƒ), the resistivity is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒÏ = 1/Ïƒ.

Since current flows radially from the inner conductor to the outer conductor, consider a cylindrical shell at a radius r of infinitesimal thickness dr. The current flows radially through the surface of this shell. The cross-sectional area for the current flow at radius r is the surface area of a cylinder of radius r and length l, namely

â€ƒâ€ƒA(r) = 2Ï€r l.

The differential resistance dR of this shell is then

â€ƒâ€ƒdR = (Ï dr) / A(r) = (1/Ïƒ) (dr / (2Ï€r l)) = (dr) / (2Ï€ r l Ïƒ).

Integrate this expression from r = a to r = b:

â€ƒâ€ƒR = âˆ«â‚áµ‡ (dr) / (2Ï€ r l Ïƒ)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = 1/(2Ï€ lÏƒ) âˆ«â‚áµ‡ (dr/r)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = 1/(2Ï€ lÏƒ) [ln(r)]â‚áµ‡
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (ln(b/a))/(2Ï€ l Ïƒ).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Step 2: Calculating the Capacitance

The capacitance per unit length of a coaxial cable filled with a homogeneous dielectric of permittivity Îµ is well-known to be

â€ƒâ€ƒC' = 2Ï€Îµ / ln(b/a).

Thus, for a cable of length l, the total capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC = C' l = (2Ï€Îµ l) / ln(b/a).

We will show that both parts of the problem may be â€œsolved by images.â€ In part (a) the potential outside a grounded sphere is produced by replacing the original dipole by an equivalent system of image charges (namely, an image dipole and an image point charge), while in (b) we note that two isolated, polarizable (i.e. conducting) spheres in an external field develop induced moments that interact to produce dipolar and quadrupolar corrections (in a multipole expansion in inverse powers of their separation).

In what follows we describe one acceptable answer. (Any answer equivalent to that given is correct.)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step (a): Dipole near a grounded conducting sphere

Assume that a dipole of moment 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒd = d xÌ‚â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (with d a scalar)
is placed on the xâ€“axis at x = L (with L > a) while a grounded (i.e. V = 0) conducting sphere of radius a is centered at the origin. (Note that the dipole moment is assumed directed along the line joining the sphereâ€™s center and the dipole; that is, its â€œaxisâ€ passes through the center of the sphere.)

It is well known (see, e.g., Jacksonâ€™s Classical Electrodynamics) that the potential produced outside the sphere by a â€œrealâ€ source located at râ‚€ together with a suitably chosen system of image charges will exactly vanish on the surface r = a. In our case one may show that one acceptable solution is to replace the dipole by an â€œimage systemâ€ consisting of

1. An image dipole
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒdâ€² = â€“ (aÂ³/LÂ³)d,
located at x = aÂ²/L, with the image dipole pointing in the same (xâ€“)direction as the original (since in our case d is along xÌ‚).

2. An image point charge
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒqâ€² = (a/LÂ²) d,
also located at x = aÂ²/L.

Thus the complete potential at a field point r (in Cartesian or spherical coordinates) may be written as the sum

â€ƒâ€ƒV({\bf r}) = V_d({\bf r}) + V_{d'}({\bf r}) + V_{q'}({\bf r}),
where

â€¢ The original dipole potential is
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒV_d({\bf r}) = d â€¢ (r â€“ L xÌ‚)/|r â€“ L xÌ‚|Â³ = d (x â€“ L)/|{\bf r} â€“ L xÌ‚|Â³
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (since d = dâ€‰xÌ‚).

â€¢ The image dipole gives
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒV_{d'}({\bf r}) = dâ€² â€¢ (r â€“ (aÂ²/L) xÌ‚)/|r â€“ (aÂ²/L) xÌ‚|Â³
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= â€“ (aÂ³/LÂ³) d (x â€“ aÂ²/L)/|{\bf r} â€“ (aÂ²/L)xÌ‚|Â³.

â€¢ The image point charge gives
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒV_{q'}({\bf r}) = \frac{q'}{|r â€“ (aÂ²/L)xÌ‚|} = \frac{(a\,d/L^2)}{|{\bf r} â€“ (aÂ²/L)xÌ‚|}.

Thus an acceptable answer is

â€ƒâ€ƒV({\bf r}) = d \, \frac{(x - L)}{\Bigl[(x - L)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ â€“ \frac{a^3}{L^3} \,d\, \frac{\Bigl(x - \frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)}
{\Bigl[\Bigl(x - \frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ + \frac{a\,d}{L^2}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2}}.

One may verify that with this choice V = 0 when r = a (i.e. on the surface of the sphere). Equivalently, one may state: â€œThe potential outside the sphere is exactly that due to the dipole at x = L together with an image dipole of strength â€“ (aÂ³/LÂ³)d and an image point charge qâ€² = (a d/LÂ²) (both placed at x = aÂ²/L).â€

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step (b): Two isolated conducting spheres in a uniform external field

Now consider two identical, isolated, conducting spheres of radius a whose centers are separated by a large distance R. Suppose that a uniform external field Eâ‚€ is applied in the direction parallel to the line joining the centers; we may take

â€ƒâ€ƒEâ‚€ = â€“Eâ‚€ áº‘â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (i.e. along the zâ€“axis).

A single isolated conducting sphere placed in a uniform field becomes polarized and acquires an induced dipole moment. (In Gaussian units one finds, for example, p = aÂ³Eâ‚€; in SI units the constant would include a factor depending on 4Ï€Îµâ‚€. Here we state the answer â€œup to conventional constantsâ€.)

When two such spheres are widely separated the field produced by one alters the polarization of the other. (This is analogous to taking into account the â€œsecondaryâ€ field in the method of images.) In a typical selfâ€“consistent analysis (see, e.g., a discussion of interacting â€œdielectricâ€ or conducting spheres) one shows that each sphere acquires an induced dipole moment which, to leading order, is just that of an isolated sphere; namely,
â€ƒâ€ƒp = aÂ³ Eâ‚€.
The next corrections arise from the dipole field of the other sphere â€“ which is proportional to Râ»Â³ â€“ so that one may write, symbolically,
â€ƒâ€ƒp = aÂ³\Bigl(Eâ‚€ + 2\frac{p}{R^3}+\cdots \Bigr)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ,
or, solving iteratively, 
â€ƒâ€ƒp = aÂ³Eâ‚€\Bigl(1+2\frac{a^3}{R^3}+\cdots\Bigr).

â€ƒ(1) the applied uniform field (â€“Eâ‚€z),
â€ƒ(2) the dipole fields arising from each sphere (each âˆ¼1/RÂ³), and

Thus, to order Râ»â´, the field is â€œmostly uniformâ€ but with corrections corresponding to the dipolar (âˆRâ»Â³) and quadrupolar (âˆRâ»â´) fields produced by the polarized spheres.

{\Bigl[\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ + \frac{a\,d}{L^2}\, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2}}\;.

Equivalently, this answer may be stated as: â€œThe potential is that of a dipole of strength d at x = L together with an image dipole of strength â€“(aÂ³/LÂ³)d and an image charge qâ€² = (a d/LÂ²) (both placed at x = aÂ²/L).â€

(b) For two isolated conducting spheres (of radius a and centerâ€“toâ€“center separation R â‰« a) placed in a uniform field Eâ‚€ (taken along the zâ€“axis), each sphere becomes polarized and acquires an induced dipole moment

â€ƒâ€ƒp = aÂ³Eâ‚€\Bigl(1+2\frac{a^3}{R^3}+\cdots\Bigr).

so that in addition to the uniform field there appear dipoleâ€“fields (scaling as 1/RÂ³) and induced quadrupole corrections (scaling as 1/Râ´).

We start with an infinite wire of small radius a carrying a charge per unit length Ïƒ. In free space (with our â€œCoulombâ€constantâ€ taken as 1 so that the potential equals Ïƒ/(2Ï€) times a logarithm) the potential around the wire (up to an additive constant) is

Now, when the wire is placed a distance b (with b â‰« a) from an infinite grounded plane, the boundary condition that V = 0 on the plane can be satisfied using the method of images. In this method the effect of the plane is replaced by an image wire. This image is located â€œbehindâ€ the plane so that if the real wire is at (0, b), the image wire is at (0, â€“b) and carries the opposite charge per unit length (â€“Ïƒ).

Thus, the net potential at any point is the superposition:
â€ƒâ€ƒÏ† = (Ïƒ/(2Ï€)) ln (1/râ‚) + (â€“Ïƒ/(2Ï€)) ln (1/râ‚‚)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= (Ïƒ/(2Ï€)) [ln (1/râ‚) â€“ ln (1/râ‚‚)]

We wish to obtain the capacitance per unit length of the wire with the metal plane (whose potential is zero). To do this, we need the potential difference between the wire surface and the plane. It is standard to choose the potential on the plane, V = 0, as our reference. In our methodâ€ofâ€images construction the potential exactly vanishes on the plane.

We wish to find the minimum radius a of a grounded sphere (centered at the origin) such that when it is placed midway between two like charges Â±Q (located at x = â€“b and x = +b, so that their separation is 2b) its induced charges cancel the mutual repulsion between the two charges.

A common method to solve such problems is the â€œmethod of images.â€ (In our case both charges are positive so â€œsimilar chargesâ€ means they repel.) For a single charge Q located a distance R from the center of a grounded conducting sphere of radius a (with R > a) the effect of the sphere is reproduced by placing an image charge

â€ƒâ€ƒQâ€² = â€“Q (a/R)

at a distance

â€ƒâ€ƒRâ€² = aÂ²/R

from the center (on the same radial line). The sphereâ€™s surface is thereby held at zero potential.

Now, in our problem the sphere is located at the origin, and there are two real charges Q located at x = +b and x = â€“b. Thus each charge â€œseesâ€ two contributions coming from the sphere: one coming from its own induced (image) charge and one coming from the image generated by the other real charge. (One can show that in problems using the method of images the force on a real charge is found by summing the Coulomb forces due to the other real charges and all of the images.)

Let us denote
â€ƒâ€ƒx â‰¡ a/bâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (dimensionless, and we expect x â‰ª 1)
so that a = x b.

For a real charge at, say, x = +b:
1. Its own image charge comes from the charge Q at x = +b. Since its distance from the sphereâ€™s center is R = b, its image charge is
â€ƒâ€ƒQâ‚â€² = â€“Q (a/b) = â€“Q x,
located on the +x axis at
â€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚â€² = aÂ²/b = xÂ² b.
The distance between the real charge at b and its own image is
â€ƒâ€ƒdâ‚ = b â€“ xÂ²b = b (1 â€“ xÂ²).

2. The other real charge at x = â€“b produces an image (with R = b) of magnitude
â€ƒâ€ƒQâ‚‚â€² = â€“Q (a/b) = â€“Q x,
but now this image is located on the â€“x axis at
â€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚‚â€² = aÂ²/b = xÂ² b.
The distance from the charge at +b to this image is
â€ƒâ€ƒdâ‚‚ = b â€“ (â€“xÂ²b) = b (1 + xÂ²).

Also, without the sphere the two real charges repel each other. Their direct repulsive force is
â€ƒâ€ƒF_R = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ²/(2b)Â²) = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ²/(4bÂ²))
(note that since the charges are alike the force on the charge at +b is directed to the +x direction).

The contributions from the induced charges (image charges) are attractive. (They have the opposite sign from Q.) Their forces (in magnitude) are given by Coulombâ€™s law:
â€ƒâ€ƒF_self = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(|Q Â· Qâ‚â€²|/dâ‚Â²) = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ² x/(bÂ² (1 â€“ xÂ²)Â²))
â€ƒâ€ƒF_other = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(|Q Â· Qâ‚‚â€²|/dâ‚‚Â²) = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ² x/(bÂ² (1 + xÂ²)Â²))
and both act in the â€“x direction.

The total force on the charge at +b is then
â€ƒâ€ƒF_total = F_R â€“ (F_self + F_other).

The question asks for the sphere to â€œneutralize their mutual repulsion,â€ i.e. cancel F_total so that
â€ƒâ€ƒF_R = F_self + F_other.
That is,
â€ƒâ€ƒ(1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ²/(4bÂ²)) = (1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€))Â·(QÂ² x/(bÂ²))Â·[1/(1 â€“ xÂ²)Â² + 1/(1 + xÂ²)Â²].

Cancel the common factor (QÂ²/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€ bÂ²)) on both sides, leaving
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/4 = x [1/(1 â€“ xÂ²)Â² + 1/(1 + xÂ²)Â²].â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(1)

Since we expect the sphere to be relatively small, x = a/b is small compared to 1. We can then expand the factors to lowest order in x:
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/(1 Â± xÂ²)Â² â‰ˆ 1 âˆ“ 2xÂ²â€ƒ (plus higher order terms)
Adding them we see that the O(xÂ²) corrections cancel:
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/(1 â€“ xÂ²)Â² + 1/(1 + xÂ²)Â² â‰ˆ 1 + 2xÂ² + 1 â€“ 2xÂ² = 2.
Thus Eq. (1) becomes
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/4 â‰ˆ 2xâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâŸ¹â€ƒâ€ƒx â‰ˆ 1/8,
and since x = a/b, we have
â€ƒâ€ƒa â‰ˆ b/8.

Thus, approximately, when a â‰ˆ b/8, the induced surface charges on the sphere exactly counteract the direct repulsion between the two charges.

Final Answer:

â€ƒâ€ƒ\[\boxed{a\approx\frac{b}{8}}\]

We will show that by a â€œmethodâ€ofâ€imagesâ€ analysis one may reduce the apparently messy infiniteâ€“image summations to answers written in a compact closed form. (Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.) In what follows we adopt (for convenience) a Cartesian coordinate with the two grounded, infinite plates at 
â€ƒâ€ƒx = 0â€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒx = 4z.
The two real charges lie in between:
â€ƒâ€ƒa charge +Q at x = zâ€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒa charge â€“Q at x = 3z.
Notice that the two charges are â€œsymmetricâ€ about the midâ€“plane x = 2z (indeed, the distances from x = 2z are z in each case) so that (as one may verify) the electric potential on this plane is zero. (This fact will be useful when â€œsummingâ€ the images.) 

The answer below is organized by parts. (One acceptable answer is as follows.)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€(a): Energy required to remove the charges

One may show that when the two â€œdipoleâ€likeâ€ charges are placed between two grounded conductors the work required to â€œpullâ€ them both out to infinity (i.e. the increase in the total electroâ€“static energy) is
â€ƒâ€ƒ
â€ƒâ€ƒW = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ z).
â€ƒâ€ƒ
There are several ways to show this. For example one may â€œbuildâ€ the configuration by first â€œturning onâ€ the charge +Q in the presence of the conductors (its interaction energy being oneâ€“half the work done against the field due to its infinite string of images) and then â€œbringing inâ€ â€“Q. By a little rearrangement (using the fact that the potential midway between the charges vanishes) the infinite series may be summed to the relatively simple answer above.
 
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€(b): Force on Each Charge

Since the methodâ€“ofâ€“images produces a unique solution the total force on, say, +Q is precisely the sum of the Coulomb forces produced by the infinite set of image charges (together with the other â€œrealâ€ â€“Q). A short (but not entirely trivial) summation shows that one acceptable answer is that the net force on the charge of magnitude Q is
â€ƒâ€ƒ
â€ƒâ€ƒF = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ zÂ²),
â€ƒâ€ƒ
with the direction being toward the midâ€“plane (so that the +Q, which lies below the midâ€“plane, is pulled upward and the â€“Q, which lies above the midâ€“plane, is pulled downward). (In other words the charges are â€œattractedâ€ so as to tend to coalesce at the midplane.)
 
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€(c): Force on Each Plate

The force on a conductor may be calculated from the field produced by all the other (real or induced) charges acting on the total induced charge. One acceptable answer is that the net force on, say, the lower plate is
â€ƒâ€ƒ
â€ƒâ€ƒF_plate = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ zÂ²),
â€ƒâ€ƒ
directed upward (i.e. toward the cavity); by Newtonâ€™s third law the upper plate is pulled downward by the same amount.
 
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€(d): Total Induced Charge on Each Plate (with both charges present)

Because the two plates are held at zero potential (and are â€œlargeâ€ so that edgeâ€“effects may be neglected) one may show that the effect of the two charges is to induce charges on the facing surfaces such that (via Gaussâ€™s law) the total induced charge on the plates is exactly that needed to â€œabsorbâ€ the field lines leaving from the charges. (A useful hint is to note that the potential on the midâ€“plane x = 2z is zero.) For example one acceptable answer is as follows. (One may show that for a single charge Q placed at a distance d from one of two grounded infinite parallel plates (separated by distance 4z) the induced charge on the plate at x = 0 is â€“Q(4z â€“ d)/(4z) while that on the other plate is â€“Q d/(4z). Applying this result to the individual charges we find:)

For the +Q at x=z (with d = z):
â€ƒâ€ƒLower plate: â€“Q (4z â€“ z)/(4z) = â€“(3Q)/4,
â€ƒâ€ƒUpper plate: â€“Q (z)/(4z) = â€“Q/4.
For the â€“Q at x=3z (remember that the sign is reversed):
â€ƒâ€ƒLower plate: â€“(â€“Q)(4z â€“ 3z)/(4z) = +Q/4,
â€ƒâ€ƒUpper plate: â€“(â€“Q)(3z)/(4z) = + (3Q)/4.

Thus the net induced charge on the lower plate is
â€ƒâ€ƒ(â€“3Q/4 + Q/4) = â€“Q/2,
and on the upper plate is
â€ƒâ€ƒ(â€“Q/4 + 3Q/4) = +Q/2.
Since the two real charges sum to zero the total charge on the two plates is also zero.
 
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€(e): Induced Charge on the Inside Surface of Each Plate when the â€“Q is Removed

Once the â€“Q charge is removed the remaining charge +Q (located at x=z) is no longer â€œbalancedâ€ by a second real charge. In that case one may show (by the methodâ€“ofâ€“images for a single charge between two grounded plates) that the induced charge on each plate is given by formulas analogous to those used in part (d): For a single charge +Q placed a distance d = z from the lower plate (with the plates separated by 4z) one obtains

â€ƒâ€ƒLower plate (the nearer one): Q_ind(lower) = â€“Q (4z â€“ z)/(4z) = â€“(3Q)/4,
â€ƒâ€ƒUpper plate (the farther one): Q_ind(upper) = â€“Q (z)/(4z) = â€“Q/4.
Thus the inside surface of the lower plate carries â€“(3Q)/4 while that of the upper plate carries â€“Q/4. (Of course the plates are connected to ground so that extra charge may flow in from â€œinfinityâ€ to hold the potentials exactly at zero.)
 
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Final Answers

An acceptable answer is therefore

â€ƒ(a)â€ƒWork required to remove the two charges from between the plates and take them to infinity:
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒW = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ z).

â€ƒ(b)â€ƒForce on each charge:
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒF = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ zÂ²), with +Q pulled upward (toward x = 2z) and â€“Q pulled downward.

â€ƒ(c)â€ƒForce on each plate:
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒF_plate = QÂ²/(16Ï€Îµâ‚€ zÂ²), with the lower plate pulled upward and the upper plate pulled downward.

â€ƒ(d)â€ƒTotal induced charge (on the inside surfaces) when both charges are present:
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒLower plate: â€“Q/2â€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒUpper plate: +Q/2.

â€ƒ(e)â€ƒOnce the â€“Q is removed (with the +Q remaining at x = z) the induced charge on the inside surface of each plate is
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒLower plate: â€“(3Q)/4,â€ƒâ€ƒUpper plate: â€“Q/4.
 
Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\[

\begin{aligned}

We wish to understand a situation in which a long cylinder of insulating material is â€œtaggedâ€ with a layer of mobile electrons so that initially the surface has a uniform charge density Ïƒâ‚€. Then an external uniform electric field Eâ‚ (directed, say, along the xâ€axis) is turned on. Although the electrons are free to move along the surface, the rest of the cylinder is an insulator (in particular, we assume it does not polarize). We are to compare this â€œmobileâ€charge layerâ€ problem to the standard problem of a charged, conducting cylinder and then work out the induced change Î´Ïƒ(Î¸) in the surface charge density for a conducting cylinder. (Here the angle Î¸ is measured around the cylinder so that cosâ€‰Î¸ is the projection along the field direction.)

Below we describe step by step the answers.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. (The Difference)

(a) In a standard electrostatic problem for a charged conductor the free charges rearrange so that the entire conductor (and hence its surface) is at the same potential. That is, the conductor â€œenforcesâ€ an equipotential boundary condition. In our present problem the only free charges are the electrons that have been sprayed onto the surface; the insulating material underneath does not supply additional mobile charges and does not polarize. Thus although the electrons can laterally redistribute, they must do so while preserving the total amount of charge on the surface. In a conductor, however, the free carriers can come in from the bulk (or leave it) so as to make the surface an equipotential.

Thus the two problems differ in that while a conducting cylinder is required to have a constant potential all over its surface, in our case the â€œmobileâ€electron layerâ€ is constrained to have a fixed (integrated) total charge and does not benefit from the extra â€œreservoirâ€ of charge that a conductor possesses. As a result, the usual â€œconductorâ€ solution for the surface charge density will apply only when the applied field is weak enough that the electrons can move around on the surface to â€œsimulateâ€ an equipotential surface. (One may say that for small Eâ‚ the electronic motion is fast enough to â€œscreenâ€ the normal component of the external field on the surface. However, if Eâ‚ is too large, the electrons will be completely pulled off (or be driven to one side) so that the solution is no longer given by the usual conductor calculation.)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 2. (The Conductor Calculation)

(b) Let us now calculate the induced charge density Ïƒ(Î¸) for a (charged) conducting cylinder. We assume:
â€¢ The cylinder is infinitely long (so we can use a twoâ€dimensional problem in the plane perpendicular to the axis).
â€¢ The cylinder has radius r.
â€¢ Initially the cylinder has a uniform surface charge density Ïƒâ‚€, so that its net charge per unit length is Q = 2Ï€rÏƒâ‚€.
â€¢ An external uniform field Eâ‚ is applied in the x-direction (i.e. along Î¸ = 0).

Because the conductor must be an equipotential, the potential V (outside, r â‰¥ r) consists of the potential of the net charge Q, the applied field, and an induced dipole contribution. (There is no induced monopole since that contribution is already contained in Q.) In polar coordinates (r,Î¸) the general solution of Laplaceâ€™s equation that vanishes at infinity [apart from the logarithmic term due to Q] is

â€ƒâ€ƒV(r,Î¸) = â€“ (Qâ„(2Ï€Îµâ‚€)) ln r â€“ Eâ‚ r cosÎ¸ + A (cosÎ¸)â„r.

The constant A is determined by the requirement that the potential V is constant on r = r (we denote the radius by r; you may alternatively call it a). In other words, we require that on the cylinderâ€™s surface the Î¸â€‘dependence vanishes:

â€ƒâ€ƒV(r,Î¸) |â‚râ‚Œrâ‚ = â€“ (Qâ„(2Ï€Îµâ‚€)) ln r â€“ Eâ‚ r cosÎ¸ + (A cosÎ¸)â„r = constant.

Since the only Î¸â€‘dependent pieces are the ones proportional to cosÎ¸, these must cancel. Hence one must have

â€ƒâ€ƒâ€“ Eâ‚ r + (Aâ„r) = 0â€ƒâŸ¹â€ƒA = rÂ²Eâ‚.

Thus the potential (outside) becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒV(r,Î¸) = â€“ (Qâ„(2Ï€Îµâ‚€)) ln r â€“ Eâ‚ r cosÎ¸ + (rÂ²Eâ‚ cosÎ¸)â„r
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = â€“ (Qâ„(2Ï€Îµâ‚€)) ln r â€“ Eâ‚ r cosÎ¸ + Eâ‚ r cosÎ¸ = â€“ (Qâ„(2Ï€Îµâ‚€)) ln r, 

when r is set equal to r (the cylinderâ€™s surface). (That is, the contributions proportional to cosÎ¸ cancel, ensuring a constant potential on the surface.)

Now, to compute the surface charge density we use the condition that the charge density is given by

Step 3. (The Range of Applicability)

For the sprayedâ€electron system on an insulating cylinder to behave as a conductor, the electrons must remain on the surface. In the answer above the net charge at angle Î¸ is

We wish to study the field

and answer several questions about it. (In what follows the constant a is a length scale and Bâ‚€ may be a constant or a slowly varying function of time.) One acceptable answer is that

â€ƒâ€ƒ(a) the field is both divergenceâ€free and curlâ€free in free space,
â€ƒâ€ƒ(b) its field lines are the hyperbolas given by xy = constant, i.e. a â€œquadrupoleâ€likeâ€ pattern that might be approximately produced by four â€œfilamentaryâ€ (i.e. line) currents (two carrying current upward and two downward) located, for example, at positions (Â±R,0) and (0,Â±R),
â€ƒâ€ƒ(c) the magnetic flux per unit â€œzâ€“lengthâ€ in the region between the origin and the field line whose closest approach is R is Bâ‚€RÂ²/(2a),
â€ƒâ€ƒ(d) a nonâ€relativistic observer moving with velocity v in the áº‘â€“direction will, by the Lorentz transformation to first order in v/c, see an electric field (equivalently, a potential difference) corresponding to an electric potential Ï†(x,y) = (Bâ‚€v/(a))xy (relative to the origin), and 
â€ƒâ€ƒ(e) if Bâ‚€ is slowly varying in time so that Bâ‚€ = Bâ‚€(t), a stationary observer sees an induced electric field given by E(x,y) = â€“(xy/(a)) (dBâ‚€/dt) áº‘.

Below we describe one stepâ€byâ€“step solution.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Step (a): Verifying Maxwellâ€™s equations

The field is 
â€ƒâ€ƒB(x,y) = (Bâ‚€/(a))(x, â€“y, 0).
Its divergence is

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Â·B = âˆ‚â‚“(Bâ‚€x/a) + âˆ‚áµ§(â€“Bâ‚€y/a) + âˆ‚ğ‘§(0)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (Bâ‚€/a) â€“ (Bâ‚€/a) = 0.
Also, since none of the components depend on z we have
â€ƒâ€ƒ(âˆ‡Ã—B)_z = âˆ‚â‚“(â€“Bâ‚€y/a) â€“ âˆ‚áµ§(Bâ‚€x/a) = 0 â€“ 0 = 0.
And the other components vanish, so
â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Ã—B = 0.
Thus the field obeys Maxwellâ€™s equations in free space (no magnetic charges and, in currentâ€“free regions, âˆ‡Ã—B = Î¼â‚€J = 0).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Step (b): Sketching the field lines and filamentary currents

A field line obeys
â€ƒâ€ƒdx/Bâ‚“ = dy/Báµ§.
That is,
â€ƒâ€ƒdx/(Bâ‚€x/a) = dy/(â€“Bâ‚€y/a)â€ƒâ€ƒâŸ¹â€ƒâ€ƒdx/x = â€“dy/y.
Separating variables, d(ln|x|) = â€“ d(ln|y|), and upon integration
â€ƒâ€ƒln|x| + ln|y| = constantâ€ƒâ€ƒâŸ¹â€ƒâ€ƒxy = constant.
Thus the field lines are the hyperbolas (or their pieces) given by xy = constant. (In particular, the â€œnullâ€ line through the origin is xy = 0, i.e. the xâ€“ and yâ€“axes.)

A quadrupolar field such as this is commonly produced by a suitable arrangement of â€œfilamentaryâ€ currents. For example one may approximate B by placing four long, thin wires (or current elements) along the zâ€“direction at the positions (x,y) = (Â±R,0) and (0,Â±R) with currents chosen so that the resulting field in the vicinity of the origin sums to B âˆ (x, â€“y). (Any arrangement of two pairs of oppositely directed currents that produces a â€œquadrupole momentâ€ is acceptable.) In a sketch one shows the hyperbolic field lines in the xâ€“y plane and marks the four current filaments (all along áº‘) with arrows indicating the direction of current (two in the +áº‘ and two in the â€“áº‘ directions).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Step (c): Magnetic flux per unit zâ€“length

When a magnetic field has no zâ€“dependence one may speak of â€œflux per unit lengthâ€ in the zâ€“direction. A very convenient way to characterize the 2D magnetic configuration is to introduce a flux function Ïˆ(x,y) defined so that
â€ƒâ€ƒBâ‚“ = âˆ‚áµ§Ïˆ,â€ƒâ€ƒBáµ§ = â€“âˆ‚â‚“Ïˆ.
For our field, one may check that
â€ƒâ€ƒÏˆ(x,y) = (Bâ‚€/(a)) x y
satisfies
â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‚áµ§Ïˆ = (Bâ‚€/(a)) x = Bâ‚“â€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€“âˆ‚â‚“Ïˆ = â€“(Bâ‚€/(a)) y = Báµ§.
Since Ïˆ is constant on field lines, its value is a â€œlabelâ€ for a particular field line. In particular, the field line that passes closest to the origin (i.e. that has its minimum distance equal to R) will have its minimum (absolute) distance when |x| = |y|. Along this line, we have
â€ƒâ€ƒÏˆ = (Bâ‚€/(a)) xÂ².
Taking x_min = R/âˆš2 so that the distance from the origin is r = âˆš(2) |x_min| = R we see that the corresponding constant is
â€ƒâ€ƒÏˆ = (Bâ‚€/(a)) (RÂ²/2) = Bâ‚€RÂ²/(2a).
(The flux â€œbetweenâ€ the Ïˆ=0 field line (through the origin) and a given field line is just the difference in Ïˆ.) Thus the magnetic flux (per unit z length) contained between the origin and the field line whose minimum distance from the origin is R is

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦ = Bâ‚€RÂ²/(2a).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

Now suppose an observer moves with a nonâ€relativistic velocity
â€ƒâ€ƒv = v áº‘.
In his frame (to first order in v/c) an electric field appears according to
â€ƒâ€ƒEâ€² = â€“v Ã— B.
Since
â€ƒâ€ƒB = (Bâ‚€/(a)) (x  xÌ‚ â€“ y  Å·)
we compute
â€ƒâ€ƒv Ã— B = v áº‘ Ã— (Bâ‚€/(a))(x xÌ‚ â€“ y Å·)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (Bâ‚€v/(a)) (áº‘ Ã— x xÌ‚ â€“ áº‘ Ã— y Å·)
Recall that áº‘ Ã— xÌ‚ = yÌ‚ and áº‘ Ã— Å· = â€“xÌ‚ so that
â€ƒâ€ƒv Ã— B = (Bâ‚€v/(a)) (x yÌ‚ + y xÌ‚).
Then
â€ƒâ€ƒEâ€² = â€“(Bâ‚€v/(a))(y xÌ‚ + x yÌ‚).
Since this induced electric field is (for our nonâ€“relativistic observer) conservative, we may define a potential Ï† by
â€ƒâ€ƒEâ€² = â€“âˆ‡Ï†.
That is,
â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‚â‚“Ï† = (Bâ‚€v/(a)) yâ€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‚áµ§Ï† = (Bâ‚€v/(a)) x.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

â€ƒâ€ƒA = (0, 0, A_z(x,y,t)),

â€ƒâ€ƒBâ‚“ = âˆ‚áµ§A_zâ€ƒâ€ƒandâ€ƒâ€ƒBáµ§ = â€“âˆ‚â‚“A_z.

We are given that an isolated soap bubble of radius Râ‚ = 1 cm is at a potential Vâ‚ = 100 V. Being an isolated charged conductor means that the total charge Q on the bubble remains fixed even if its size changes. For the initial bubble:  
â€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚ = 1 cm = 0.01 m,  
â€ƒâ€ƒCâ‚ = 4Ï€Îµâ‚€(0.01 m).

Since the bubble is at a potential Vâ‚ = 100 V, the charge is  
â€ƒâ€ƒQ = Câ‚ Vâ‚ = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€ Â· 0.01) Ã— 100 = 4Ï€Îµâ‚€.  
Thus the magnitude of the charge is Q = 4Ï€Îµâ‚€ (note that the units work out correctly).

Step 2. Write the expression for the electrostatic energy.

Step 3. Compute the initial and final energies.

â€ƒâ€ƒUâ‚ = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€)/(2Â·0.01) = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€)/(0.02).

â€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚‚ = 1 mm = 0.001 m,

Thus,
â€ƒâ€ƒUâ‚‚ = QÂ²/(2Câ‚‚) = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€)Â²/(2 Â· (4Ï€Îµâ‚€Â·0.001))  
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€)/(2Â·0.001) = (4Ï€Îµâ‚€)/(0.002).

Step 1. Write the capacitance for a parallel-plate capacitor. For circular plates of radius r (with r â‰« d) we have:

â€ƒâ€ƒC = Îµâ‚€A/d,â€ƒâ€ƒwithâ€ƒA = Ï€rÂ².

Thus, the capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC = (Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²)/d.

Step 2. Determine the energy stored in the capacitor. For a capacitor, the energy stored is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒU = QÂ²/(2C).

Since Q is constant, we have

â€ƒâ€ƒU = QÂ²/(2C) = QÂ²/[2(Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²/d)] = (QÂ²d)/(2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²).

Step 3. Calculate the initial and final energies. Let the initial distance be d and the final distance be dâ€². Then,

â€ƒâ€ƒU_initial = (QÂ²d)/(2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²)â€ƒ andâ€ƒ U_final = (QÂ²dâ€²)/(2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²).

The change in the stored energy when the plate separation is changed slowly is

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ”U = U_final âˆ’ U_initial = (QÂ²/(2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²))(dâ€² âˆ’ d).

Step 4. Relate the change in energy to the work performed. In a quasi-static process the work done by the external forces (the work done by slowly moving the plates) is equal to the change in the stored energy. Hence,

â€ƒâ€ƒW = Î”U = (QÂ²/(2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²))(dâ€² âˆ’ d).

Step 5. Express the result in terms of the initial potential V. Initially, when the capacitor is charged to a potential V (while connected to the circuit), the charge is

â€ƒâ€ƒQ = CV = (Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²/d)V.

Substitute this expression for Q back into the work expression:

â€ƒâ€ƒW = [((Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²V/d)Â²) / (2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²)](dâ€² âˆ’ d)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = [(Îµâ‚€Â²Ï€Â²râ´VÂ²/dÂ²) / (2Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²)](dâ€² âˆ’ d)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = [Îµâ‚€Ï€rÂ²VÂ²/(2dÂ²)](dâ€² âˆ’ d).

The total charge Q is uniformly distributed over the surface of a sphere with radius r. Therefore, the surface charge density Ïƒ is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒÏƒ = Q / (4Ï€rÂ²).

Step 2: Determine the Electric Field on the Surface

For a sphere with a uniform surface charge distribution, Gaussâ€™ law tells us that the electric field just outside the surface is

â€ƒâ€ƒEâ‚Š = Ïƒ / Îµâ‚€ = Q / (4Ï€Îµâ‚€rÂ²).

However, on the inside of a conductor (or on the inner side of a charged shell) the electric field is zero. Thus, on the surface there is a discontinuity:
â€ƒâ€ƒEâ‚Š â€“ Eâ‚‹ = Ïƒ/Îµâ‚€,
with Eâ‚‹ = 0. 

A common prescription is to take the effective electric field acting on the surface charges as the average of the fields just outside and just inside. That is, we define the effective field E_eff to be

â€ƒâ€ƒE_eff = (Eâ‚Š + Eâ‚‹) / 2 = (1/2) Eâ‚Š = (1/2) (Q / (4Ï€Îµâ‚€rÂ²)).

Step 3: Calculate the Force on a Small Charge Element

Consider a small element of charge dq on the surface of the sphere. The only force on this charge element (due to the other charges) comes from the effective field E_eff produced by the rest of the charge. Therefore, the force on dq is

â€ƒâ€ƒdF = (dq)(E_eff).

Substituting the expression for E_eff we find

â€ƒâ€ƒdF = dq * (1/2) (Q / (4Ï€Îµâ‚€rÂ²)).

This can be arranged as

â€ƒâ€ƒdF = (1/2) ( (1/4Ï€Îµâ‚€)(Q/rÂ²) ) dq.

Step 4: Direction of the Force

Due to the spherical symmetry of the charge distribution, the non-radial (tangential) components of the force cancel each other out. Only the radial components survive, and they point outward. Thus, the force on dq is purely radial and outward.

Final Answer

The force on a small charge element dq on the sphere is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒdF = (1/2) (1/4Ï€Îµâ‚€)(Q/rÂ²) dq.

An observer B, moving along the wire with speed v (along the zâ€“axis, say) will, however, see a different mixture of electric and magnetic fields and a nonzero net charge density. Below we explain stepâ€byâ€step.

We start by noting that the geometry is spherically symmetric, so the electric field has only a radial component. However, the twist is that the conductivity of the material between the spheres is not constant but depends on the local electric field according to

where K is a constant.

Step 1. Determine the local current density

In a region with a local electric field E(r), Ohmâ€™s law (in its differential form) gives the current density as

â€ƒâ€ƒJ(r) = Ïƒ E(r).

Substituting the given relation for Ïƒ, we obtain

â€ƒâ€ƒJ(r) = (K E(r)) E(r) = K [E(r)]Â².

Step 2. Express the total current in radial geometry

Because of spherical symmetry, the total current I passing through a spherical shell of radius r is given by the current density multiplied by the area of the sphere:

â€ƒâ€ƒI = J(r) Â· 4Ï€rÂ².

Substitute the expression for J(r):

â€ƒâ€ƒI = 4Ï€rÂ² K [E(r)]Â²â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(1)

Since I is constant (steady state), we can solve for E(r):

â€ƒâ€ƒ[E(r)]Â² = I/(4Ï€K rÂ²)
â€ƒâ€ƒE(r) = âˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] / r.â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(2)

Step 3. Relate the potential difference V to the electric field

â€ƒâ€ƒV = âˆ«[a to b] E(r) dr.

Substitute our expression (2) for E(r):

â€ƒâ€ƒV = âˆ«[a to b]  âˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] / r dr
â€ƒâ€ƒ= âˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] âˆ«[a to b] (1/r) dr
â€ƒâ€ƒ= âˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] ln(b/a).â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(3)

Step 4. Solve for the current I

Solving equation (3) for âˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] gives:

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆš[I/(4Ï€K)] = V / ln(b/a).

Squaring both sides we get:

â€ƒâ€ƒI/(4Ï€K) = [V / ln(b/a)]Â².

Thus,

â€ƒâ€ƒI = 4Ï€K [V / ln(b/a)]Â²
â€ƒâ€ƒI = (4Ï€K VÂ²) / [ln(b/a)]Â².â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(4)

Final Answer:

\[

\]

In what follows we present one acceptable solution in SI units (with the final answers also given in Gauss for the magnetic field in part (a)). (One must be a bit careful since many texts on synchrotron radiation use Gaussian units; just be sure to use a selfâ€“consistent system.)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. (a) Finding the Required Field

An electron of (relativistic) momentum
â€ƒâ€ƒp = Î³ m v 
moves in a magnetic field B where the Lorentz force provides the required centripetal force. In SI one has

â€ƒâ€ƒe v B = p v/Râ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ[since the magnetic force is perpendicular to v, and so gives the â€œcentripetal forceâ€]

But more directly the wellâ€“known â€œcyclotron radiusâ€ for a relativistic particle is

â€ƒâ€ƒR = p/(eB).

For ultraâ€“relativistic motion we have v â‰ƒ c and the total energy is E â‰ƒ Î³ mcÂ². Since (in any relativistic treatment) p = Î³ m v and here v â‰ƒ c we have

â€ƒâ€ƒp â‰ƒ E/c.

Thus the condition R = p/(eB) becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒR = (E/c)/(eB)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ‡’ B = E/(e c R).

This is our analytical answer. (In SI units, E must be in Joules, e in Coulombs, c in m/s, and R in m. In SI the field comes out in Tesla; to convert to Gauss use 1 Tesla = 10â´ Gauss.)

Now let us compute the number. We are given:
â€ƒâ€ƒR = 30 m,
â€ƒâ€ƒE = 2.5Ã—10â¹ eV.

First, convert the energy to Joules. Since
â€ƒâ€ƒ1 eV = 1.602Ã—10â»Â¹â¹ J,
we have
â€ƒâ€ƒE = 2.5Ã—10â¹ eV â‰ƒ 2.5Ã—10â¹ Ã— 1.602Ã—10â»Â¹â¹ J â‰ƒ 4.005Ã—10â»Â¹â° J.

Next, use the following constants:
â€ƒâ€ƒe = 1.602Ã—10â»Â¹â¹ C,
â€ƒâ€ƒc = 3.00Ã—10â¸ m/s.

Thus,
â€ƒâ€ƒB = E/(e c R)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (4.005Ã—10â»Â¹â° J) / [ (1.602Ã—10â»Â¹â¹ C)(3.00Ã—10â¸ m/s)(30 m) ].

Let us compute the denominator:
â€ƒâ€ƒe c R = 1.602Ã—10â»Â¹â¹ Ã— 3.00Ã—10â¸ Ã— 30 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = 1.602Ã—3.00Ã—30 Ã—10^(â€“19+8) 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (1.602Ã—90) Ã—10^(â€“11)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ â‰ƒ 144.18Ã—10â»Â¹Â¹ = 1.4418Ã—10â»â¹ (in SI units).

Thus,
â€ƒâ€ƒB â‰ƒ (4.005Ã—10â»Â¹â°)/(1.4418Ã—10â»â¹) â‰ƒ 0.2777 Tesla.

In Gauss, 
â€ƒâ€ƒB â‰ƒ 0.2777 Ã— 10â´ Gauss â‰ƒ 2777 Gauss.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 2. (b) Fractional Energy Loss per Revolution

Although we have assumed that the electron does not lose energy (so that its orbit is circular), in fact an accelerated charge radiates. (For synchrotron radiation one must use the relativistic Larmorâ€“formula.) In Gaussian units (which are often most convenient for radiation problems) the instantaneous power radiated from a charge moving with acceleration perpendicular to its velocity is

â€ƒâ€ƒ(eÂ²/(mâ´ câ¸)) EÂ³ = (eÂ²/(m cÂ²)) (E/(m cÂ²))Â³ = r_e (E/(mcÂ²))Â³.

â€ƒâ€ƒr_e â‰ƒ 2.818Ã—10â»Â¹âµ m,
but it is easier to use a standard synchrotronâ€“radiation formula.)

Using:

â€ƒâ€ƒmcÂ² = 0.511Ã—10â¶ eVâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (so that Î³ = E/(mcÂ²) â‰ƒ 2.5Ã—10â¹ / 0.511Ã—10â¶ â‰ƒ 4893),
â€ƒâ€ƒR = 30 m,

â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (4Ï€/3) (2.818Ã—10â»Â¹âµ/30) (4893Â³).

Now, 4893Â³ â‰ƒ (4.893Ã—10Â³)Â³. Compute
â€ƒâ€ƒ(4.893Ã—10Â³)Â³ = 4.893Â³Ã—10â¹.
A quick calculation shows 4.893Â³ â‰ƒ 117 (approximately).

Thus,
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ³Â³ â‰ƒ 1.17Ã—10Â¹Â¹.

Also,
â€ƒâ€ƒr_e/R = 2.818Ã—10â»Â¹âµ/30 â‰ƒ 9.393Ã—10â»Â¹â·.

Now,
â€ƒâ€ƒ(4Ï€/3) â‰ƒ 4.18879.

Therefore,
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ”E/E â‰ƒ 4.18879 Ã— (9.393Ã—10â»Â¹â·) Ã— (1.17Ã—10Â¹Â¹)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ â‰ƒ 4.18879 Ã— (1.099Ã—10â»âµ)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ â‰ƒ 4.60Ã—10â»âµ.

Thus, the fractional energy loss per revolution is about 4.6Ã—10â»âµ (that is, about 0.005% of the particleâ€™s energy per turn).

An acceptable answer is:

Numerically, with E = 2.5Ã—10â¹ eV and R = 30 m, one finds

Numerically, this gives

Step 1. Find the Initial Capacitance (Câ‚)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. (a) Show that Aâ‚“ = 0.

Recall that the Lorenz gauge condition, in the absence of the scalar potential (Ï• = 0), reduces to

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Â·A = 0.

Now, since A is a function of the variable (x â€“ ct) only, the derivatives with respect to y and z vanish and we have

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‡Â·A = âˆ‚Aâ‚“/âˆ‚x.

Thus the gauge condition becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‚Aâ‚“/âˆ‚x = 0.

This tells us that Aâ‚“ can depend only on time; however, because A itself is a function only of (x â€“ ct) (and not an independent function of time), it can only be a constant. In other words, Aâ‚“ must be independent of both x and time. Now, applying the boundary condition that the vector potential goes to zero for sufficiently large values of (x â€“ ct) (i.e. where the wave is not present), we conclude that the constant must be zero. Hence

â€ƒâ€ƒAâ‚“ = 0.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 2. (b) Show that pâ‚âŠ¥â‚ = â€“e A where pâ‚âŠ¥â‚ is the particle momentum in the yâ€“z plane.

For a charged particle in an electromagnetic field, the relativistic Lagrangian (in units where c remains explicit) is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒL = â€“mcÂ²âˆš(1 â€“ vÂ²/cÂ²) + e v Â· A.

The canonical momentum is obtained by differentiating the Lagrangian with respect to the velocity:

and

Here the term â€“Eâ‚€r cosÎ¸ corresponds to the applied uniform field (with Ï† â†’ âˆ’Eâ‚€z where z = r cosÎ¸) and the second term represents the field produced by the polarization of the sphere.
 
â€¢ Inside (r < R):

Letâ€™s determine the radial field components (recall that E = â€“âˆ‡Ï†).

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ‚Ï†_out/âˆ‚r = â€“Eâ‚€ cosÎ¸ â€“ (â€“2B cosÎ¸)/rÂ³ = â€“Eâ‚€ cosÎ¸ â€“ 2B cosÎ¸/rÂ³.
Thus,

where C is the capacitance.

Step 2: Effect of inserting a dielectric  
A dielectric increases the capacitance. When a dielectric (with dielectric constant Îº > 1) is inserted, the effective capacitance of the capacitor increases as more of the dielectric fills the gap between the plates.

Step 3: Energy change due to dielectric insertion  
Since Q is constant, an increase in capacitance C results in a decrease in stored energy U. In other words, inserting the dielectric lowers the systemâ€™s energy:
â€ƒâ€ƒdC/dx > 0 â€ƒâ‡’â€ƒ dU/dx = -QÂ²/(2CÂ²) (dC/dx) < 0.
This decrease in energy means that the system is driven to pull the dielectric further in to lower its energy even more.

Step 4: Force on the dielectric  
The force on the dielectric is given by  
â€ƒâ€ƒF = -dU/dx.  
Since dU/dx is negative (energy decreases as more dielectric is inserted), F becomes positive, indicating that the force is directed so as to pull the dielectric further into the capacitor.

â€ƒâ€ƒUâ‚ = (Â½) Q Vâ‚

â€ƒâ€ƒVâ‚ = Q/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€) (1/b â€“ 1/a).

Thus, the initial energy is

â€ƒâ€ƒUâ‚ = Â½ Q [Q/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€)(1/b â€“ 1/a)] = QÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)(1/b â€“ 1/a).

Now, the outer sphere is slowly contracted from radius a to a new radius aâ€² (with aâ€² > b so that the inner sphere remains inside the outer one). After this change, the potential on the inner sphere becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒVâ‚‚ = Q/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€)(1/b â€“ 1/aâ€²)

â€ƒâ€ƒUâ‚‚ = QÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)(1/b â€“ 1/aâ€²).

Since the work done by the electric forces (a conservative force in this quasistatic process) is equal to the decrease in the stored energy, we have

â€ƒâ€ƒW = Uâ‚ â€“ Uâ‚‚
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = QÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)[(1/b â€“ 1/a) â€“ (1/b â€“ 1/aâ€²)]
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = QÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)(1/aâ€² â€“ 1/a).

In special relativity, when an object experiences constant proper acceleration g, its motion along the x-axis (in the inertial â€œfixed starsâ€ frame) can be conveniently described in terms of the proper time Ï„ of the spaceship. One standard set of equations for such motion is

â€ƒâ€ƒv(Ï„) = câ€‰tanh(gÏ„/c)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(1)
â€ƒâ€ƒt(Ï„) = (c/g)â€‰sinh(gÏ„/c)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(2)
â€ƒâ€ƒx(Ï„) = (cÂ²/g)[cosh(gÏ„/c) â€“ 1]â€ƒâ€ƒ(3)

Notice that equation (3) tells us the distance traveled x as a function of the proper time Ï„.

Our goal is to express x as a function of the velocity v. From equation (1), we have

â€ƒâ€ƒtanh(gÏ„/c) = v/c.

Recall the hyperbolic identity for cosh in terms of tanh:

â€ƒâ€ƒcosh(gÏ„/c) = 1/âˆš[1 â€“ tanhÂ²(gÏ„/c)]
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚ = 1/âˆš[1 â€“ (v/c)Â²]
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚ = Î³â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (where Î³ is the usual Lorentz factor).

Thus, substituting this into equation (3) we obtain

â€ƒâ€ƒx = (cÂ²/g)[Î³ â€“ 1]â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(4)

Or explicitly,

â€ƒâ€ƒx = (cÂ²/g) [1/âˆš(1 â€“ vÂ²/cÂ²) â€“ 1].

This is our desired answer.

Let us quickly check the non-relativistic limit (v << c). Expanding the square root to second order we have

â€ƒâ€ƒ1/âˆš(1 â€“ vÂ²/cÂ²) â‰ˆ 1 + (1/2)(vÂ²/cÂ²),
â€ƒâ€ƒthusâ€ƒx â‰ˆ (cÂ²/g)[1 + (1/2)(vÂ²/cÂ²) â€“ 1] = vÂ²/(2g),

â€ƒâ€ƒ\]

We wish to determine three things for a cylindrical capacitor of length L with an inner conductor of radius a, an outer thin shell of radius b, and a dielectric (of dielectric constant Îµ) filling the space between them (so that the permittivity is Îµâ‚€Îµ):

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  
Step (a): The Electric Field

When the capacitor is charged with charge Q (assumed to reside on the inner conductor; by symmetry the outer shell gets a compensating âˆ’Q), we may exploit cylindrical symmetry. (We assume that L is long so that end effects may be neglected.)

Consider a cylindrical Gaussian surface co-axial with the conductors having radius r, where a < r < b, and length L. (End caps do not contribute because the field is radial, c.f. the symmetry.) Gaussâ€™s law states that

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ® EÂ·dA = Q_enclosed/(Îµâ‚€Îµ).

Because E is radially directed and uniformly distributed over the curved surface, the leftâ€side becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒE(r) Â· (2Ï€rL).

Thus,
â€ƒâ€ƒE(r)Â·2Ï€rL = Q/(Îµâ‚€Îµ)
so
â€ƒâ€ƒE(r) = Q/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€ Îµ L r).

Thus, the electric field in the region a < r < b is

â€ƒâ€ƒE(r) = Q/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ L r).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  
Step (b): The Capacitance

The capacitance is defined as
â€ƒâ€ƒC = Q/V,
where the potential difference V between the inner and outer conductors is obtained by integrating the electric field from r = a to r = b:

â€ƒâ€ƒV = âˆ«â‚áµ‡ E(r) dr = âˆ«â‚áµ‡ [Q/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ L r)] dr
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = [Q/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ L)] ln(b/a).

Solving for Q/V we have

â€ƒâ€ƒQ/V = (2Ï€ Îµâ‚€ Îµ L)/ln(b/a).

Thus, the capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC = 2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ L/ln(b/a).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  
Step (c): The Force on a Partially Pulled-Out Dielectric Connected to a Battery

Now suppose that the capacitor is connected to a battery which maintains a fixed potential difference V. When the dielectric is only partly inserted (say with a length x inside the capacitor and a remaining length L â€“ x filled with vacuum), the capacitor essentially becomes a combination of two capacitors in parallel (since the voltage V is the same along the length). The capacitance per unit length in the two regions are:
â€ƒâ€ƒwith dielectric:â€ƒc_d = 2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ/ln(b/a),
â€ƒâ€ƒwithout dielectric:â€ƒcâ‚€ = 2Ï€ Îµâ‚€/ln(b/a).

Thus, the total capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC(x) = c_d x + câ‚€ (L â€“ x)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = [2Ï€ Îµâ‚€/ln(b/a)] [Îµ x + (L â€“ x)]
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = [2Ï€ Îµâ‚€/ln(b/a)] [L + (Îµ â€“ 1)x].

Since the capacitor is connected to a battery (fixed V), the stored energy (taking into account that the battery supplies energy so that on insertion the system releases energy) is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒU = â€“Â½ C(x) VÂ²,
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = â€“Â½ VÂ² [2Ï€ Îµâ‚€/ln(b/a)] [L + (Îµ â€“ 1)x].

The negative sign is conventional for a system maintained at constant voltage (it shows that an increased capacitance lowers the energy, i.e. the capacitor â€œwantsâ€ to pull the dielectric in).

Now, the force on the dielectric is obtained from the spatial derivative of U with respect to x. (In effect, if U(x) changes, then there is a force tending to pull the dielectric in or out.) Specifically, we have

â€ƒâ€ƒF = â€“dU/dx.

Differentiate U with respect to x:

â€ƒâ€ƒdU/dx = â€“Â½ VÂ² [2Ï€ Îµâ‚€/ln(b/a)] (Îµ â€“ 1)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = â€“Ï€ Îµâ‚€ (Îµ â€“ 1) VÂ²/ln(b/a).

Thus, 
â€ƒâ€ƒF = â€“(dU/dx) = Ï€ Îµâ‚€ (Îµ â€“ 1) VÂ²/ln(b/a).

Notice the sign: dU/dx is negative so F is positive. This positive force (taking x to be the length of dielectric inserted) means that the capacitor is â€œpullingâ€ the dielectric further into the capacitor. Therefore, in order to hold the dielectric at a fixed partially inserted position, one must apply an external force of equal magnitude but in the opposite direction (i.e. pulling the dielectric out) to oppose this attractive force.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€  
Final Answers

(b) The capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC = 2Ï€ Îµâ‚€Îµ L/ln(b/a).

(c) The force required (magnitude) to hold the dielectric partly inserted (with x being the inserted length) is

â€ƒâ€ƒF = Ï€ Îµâ‚€ (Îµ â€“ 1) VÂ²/ln(b/a),

and it must be applied outward (i.e. opposite to the direction in which the capacitor is pulling the dielectric in) to keep the dielectric stationary.

The total energy stored in the electric field is found by integrating the energy density over all space. Only the region r â‰¥ b contributes:

â€ƒâ€ƒU = âˆ«[r=b to âˆ] u(r) dÏ„

Now consider a spherical capacitor made of two concentric spheres:

We begin by writing Faradayâ€™s law for the loop. When the electromagnet is turned on, the magnetic flux through the circular loop changes from zero to

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦ = B (Ï€aÂ²),

since the loopâ€™s area is A = Ï€aÂ².

Because the magnetic field is uniform over the loop and the field lines are perpendicular to the plane of the loop (its plane is parallel to the pole faces), the flux is simply

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦ = BÏ€aÂ².

Faradayâ€™s law tells us that the induced emf in the loop is

â€ƒâ€ƒâ„° = - dÎ¦/dt.

In our case, as the field is switched on from 0 to B (over some time interval), the changing flux produces an emf which drives a current I in the loop. Applying Kirchhoffâ€™s loop rule, taking into account the self-inductance L and the total resistance R, the circuit equation is

â€ƒâ€ƒL (dI/dt) + R I = - dÎ¦/dt.

Our goal is to find the total electric charge q that flows past any point on the loop. This total charge is given by integrating the current over time:

â€ƒâ€ƒq = âˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ I(t) dt.

To find q, integrate the entire circuit equation with respect to time from t = 0 (when the field is off and the current is zero) until t = âˆ (when the current eventually goes to zero because the emf has vanished after the flux stops changing).

Integrate each term in the circuit equation:

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ [L (dI/dt) + R I] dt = - âˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ dÎ¦/dt dt.

Letâ€™s evaluate the left-hand side term by term.

1. For the inductor term:

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ L (dI/dt) dt = L [I(âˆ) - I(0)].

Since the current starts at zero, I(0) = 0, and after the field has been switched on and the transient dies out, there is no more induced emf and the current decays back to zero so that I(âˆ) = 0. (Note that although a momentary current flows during the change in flux, the final steady state has I = 0 because there is no source maintaining a current in the loop.) Thus, the inductor term becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒL [I(âˆ) - I(0)] = L (0 - 0) = 0.

2. For the resistor term:

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ R I dt = R âˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ I dt = Rq â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ (since q = âˆ« I dt).

Now, the right-hand side:

â€ƒâ€ƒ- âˆ«â‚€â½âˆâ¾ dÎ¦/dt dt = -[Î¦(âˆ) - Î¦(0)] = -[BÏ€aÂ² - 0] = -BÏ€aÂ².

So the integrated circuit equation becomes

â€ƒâ€ƒ0 + Rq = -BÏ€aÂ².

Thus we have

â€ƒâ€ƒRq = -BÏ€aÂ².

The negative sign reflects Lenzâ€™s law (the induced current opposes the change). Since we are asked for the total electric charge that flows past any point (its magnitude), we take the absolute value:

â€ƒâ€ƒq = (BÏ€aÂ²)/R.

Note that the selfâ€inductance L does not appear in the final expression. It affects the time dependence of the current but not the overall integrated charge.

Therefore, the final answer is

â€ƒâ€ƒq = (Ï€aÂ²B)/R.

Finally, in boxed form:

â€ƒâ€ƒ\[ \boxed{q = \frac{\pi a^2 B}{R}}. \]

Below is one common way to solve a problem like â€œCalculate the energy in the 3â€‰Î¼F capacitor in Fig.â€‰3.17â€ when the network is that of a battery supplying two branchesâ€”one branch having a series pair of capacitors (3â€‰Î¼F and 6â€‰Î¼F) and the other branch having a 2â€‰Î¼F capacitor. (This is the circuit used in many textbooks; see, for example, Fig.â€‰3.17 in some texts.) In our analysis we assume that the battery voltage is 12â€‰V. (If the battery voltage were different, the answer would scale accordingly.) 

Letâ€™s step through the solution:

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Stepâ€‰1. Identify the Network and Its Simplification

Suppose we have the following circuit:
â€ƒâ€¢ A 12â€‰V battery is connected to two branches (the branches are in parallel, so the voltage across each branch is 12â€‰V).
â€ƒâ€¢ In Branch A the 3â€‰Î¼F capacitor is in series with the 6â€‰Î¼F capacitor.
â€ƒâ€¢ In Branch B there is a single 2â€‰Î¼F capacitor.

Because the branches are in parallel the voltage across each branch is 12â€‰V.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Stepâ€‰2. Find the Equivalent Capacitance of the Series Pair

For two capacitors in series the equivalent capacitance is given by
â€ƒâ€ƒC_series = (Câ‚Câ‚‚)/(Câ‚ + Câ‚‚).

Substitute Câ‚ = 3â€‰Î¼F and Câ‚‚ = 6â€‰Î¼F:
â€ƒâ€ƒC_series = (3â€‰Î¼F Â· 6â€‰Î¼F)/(3â€‰Î¼F + 6â€‰Î¼F) = (18â€‰Î¼FÂ²)/(9â€‰Î¼F) = 2â€‰Î¼F.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Stepâ€‰3. Determine the Charge on the Series Branch

Since the 2â€‰Î¼F (the equivalent capacitance of the series combination) is connected directly across the 12â€‰V supply, the charge on that branch is 
â€ƒâ€ƒQ_series = C_series Â· V = (2â€‰Î¼F)(12â€‰V) = 24â€‰Î¼C.

Remember that for capacitors in series the same charge appears on each capacitor. 

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 
Stepâ€‰4. Find the Voltage Across the 3â€‰Î¼F Capacitor

â€ƒâ€ƒVâ‚ƒ = Q_series / Câ‚ƒ = (24â€‰Î¼C)/(3â€‰Î¼F) = 8â€‰V.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

â€ƒâ€ƒU = Â½ Â· (3Ã—10â»â¶â€‰F) Â· (8â€‰V)Â² 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = Â½ Â· 3Ã—10â»â¶ Â· 64 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (1.5Ã—10â»â¶) Â· 64 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = 96Ã—10â»â¶â€‰J 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = 96â€‰Î¼J.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

We start from a hydrogenâ€atomâ€“like model: a light particle (mass m and charge q) orbits a fixed heavy particle (charge â€“q) in a circular orbit of radius R. â€ƒâ€ƒP = (qÂ²aÂ²)/(6Ï€ Îµâ‚€ cÂ³)

â€ƒâ€ƒa = vÂ²/R.

But Newtonâ€™s second law for circular motion tells us

â€ƒâ€ƒm vÂ²/R = F = k_e (qÂ²/RÂ²),

with the Coulomb constant k_e = 1/(4Ï€ Îµâ‚€). Thus

â€ƒâ€ƒvÂ² = (k_e qÂ²)/(m R)

and

â€ƒâ€ƒa = vÂ²/R = k_e qÂ²/(m RÂ²).

Substitute a into the Larmor formula:

â€ƒâ€ƒP = (qÂ²/(6Ï€ Îµâ‚€ cÂ³)) Â· (k_eÂ² qâ´/(mÂ² Râ´))
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (k_eÂ² qâ¶)/(6Ï€ Îµâ‚€ cÂ³ mÂ² Râ´).

Since k_e = 1/(4Ï€ Îµâ‚€), one has k_eÂ² = 1/(16Ï€Â² Îµâ‚€Â²), so

â€ƒâ€ƒP = (qâ¶)/(6Ï€ Îµâ‚€ cÂ³ mÂ² Râ´) Â· 1/(16Ï€Â² Îµâ‚€Â²)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = qâ¶/(96 Ï€Â³ Îµâ‚€Â³ cÂ³ mÂ² Râ´).

The total (mechanical) energy of the orbit in a Coulomb potential is

â€ƒâ€ƒE = K + U = (Â½ mvÂ²) â€“ (k_e qÂ²/R).

For a circular orbit one finds from the virial theorem that K = â€“Â½ U so that

â€ƒâ€ƒE = â€“ (k_e qÂ²)/(2R).

As the particle radiates, its energy decreases. We assume the energy loss is entirely due to radiation, so that

â€ƒâ€ƒdE/dt = â€“P.

But E is a function of R so that

â€ƒâ€ƒdE/dt = (dE/dR)(dR/dt).

Since

Since k_e = 1/(4Ï€ Îµâ‚€), we have 1/k_e = 4Ï€ Îµâ‚€, so

Thus, the differential equation for R(t) is

We now wish to know the time T required for the radius to shrink from R (initial) to R/2. Separating variables,

solution:
We wish to calculate the work done by an external agent in moving a charge q from infinity to the center of a hollow conducting spherical shell. (We shall neglect the â€œselfâ€energyâ€ of bringing an isolated point charge in; we are computing the interaction energy that is assembled during the process.)

In the final state the initially neutral conductor has rearranged its free charges so that:
â€ƒâ€“ a total charge â€“q is induced on the inner surface (which, since the cavity is spherical, is distributed uniformly on the spherical surface of radius R), and 
â€ƒâ€“ a charge +q appears on the outer surface (distributed uniformly on the spherical surface of radius R + t, where t is the shellâ€™s thickness).

A basic fact about a uniformly charged spherical shell is that the potential inside it (i.e. at all points inside the shell) is constant and equal to that at its (spherical) surface. (We take the usual constant in Coulombâ€™s Law as k = 1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€).)

Thus, the potentials at the center of the sphere due to the two induced charge distributions are as follows:

1. The inner surface (charge â€“q uniformly on a spherical surface of radius R) produces at the center a potential 
â€ƒâ€ƒV_inner = (k Ã— (â€“q))/R = â€“(kq)/R.
2. The outer surface (charge +q uniformly on a spherical surface of radius R + t) produces at the center a potential 
â€ƒâ€ƒV_outer = (k Ã— (+q))/(R+t) = kq/(R+t).

Note that the free charge q that we brought in also â€œseesâ€ these potentials due to the induced charges. (One may show, via a careful assembly of the charge, that the relevant work done to bring the charge from infinity is oneâ€half the â€œinteraction energyâ€, namely Â½ qV, where V is the potential at the location of the q due only to the induced charges.)

Thus the net induced potential at the center is
â€ƒâ€ƒV_ind = V_inner + V_outer = â€“(kq)/R + kq/(R+t).

Then the work done by the external agent is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒW = Â½Â·qÂ·V_ind
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = Â½Â·qÂ·[ â€“(kq)/R + kq/(R+t) ]
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = (kqÂ²/2) [1/(R+t) â€“ 1/R].

Recalling that k = 1/(4Ï€Îµâ‚€), we may write

â€ƒâ€ƒW = (qÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)) [ 1/(R+t) â€“ 1/R ].

A few comments are in order:
â€ƒâ€¢ Notice that if the shell were infinitely thin (t = 0) the potential from the two surfaces would cancel (since then R + t = R) and the work would be zero. Indeed, when a very thin closed conductor has no separate â€œinternalâ€ and â€œexternalâ€ surfaces (when the hole is not there) the field inside is zero and there is no net work required.
â€ƒâ€¢ If t > 0 then clearly 1/(R+t) < 1/R. Thus the bracket is negative, meaning that the work done by the external agent is negative. (Physically, this means that the induced charges set up an attractive force which would do positive work on the charge. To insert the charge slowly, the agent must â€œcontrolâ€ the motion, and ends up doing â€œnegative workâ€ â€“ that is, energy is actually released by the system.)

Thus, our final answer is

â€ƒâ€ƒW = (qÂ²/(8Ï€Îµâ‚€)) [ 1/(R+t) â€“ 1/R ].

In boxed form our final answer is

â€ƒâ€ƒ\[
â€ƒâ€ƒ\boxed{W =\frac{q^2}{8\pi\varepsilon_0}\left(\frac{1}{R+t}-\frac{1}{R}\right)}
â€ƒâ€ƒ\]

We wish to find the interaction energy (or potential energy) of a point charge q located in vacuum at a distance x from a flat interface with a semiâ€infinite dielectric medium, where the dielectric constant is K. (The â€œdistance xâ€ means the point charge is at a distance x from the interface; we imagine the dielectric fills, say, z < 0 while the charge is at z = x > 0.)

Step 1. Using the Method of Images

For many problems involving interfaces between media, one may use an imageâ€“charge method to represent the effect of the boundary. In the case of a charge q in vacuum (permittivity Îµâ‚€) near a dielectric (permittivity Îµ = KÎµâ‚€) the potential in the region of the charge (i.e. in the vacuum) is given by the same potential as the combination of:
â€ƒâ€¢ The real charge q at z = x,
â€ƒâ€¢ An image charge qâ€² placed at the mirror point z = â€“x.

The magnitude of the image charge is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒqâ€² = (1 â€“ K)/(1 + K) q.

Note that when K = 1 (i.e. when the dielectric constant is the same as the vacuum), qâ€² = 0 and there is no interface effect. On the other hand, for K â†’ âˆ (a perfect conductor) qâ€² â†’ â€“q, which is the familiar imageâ€“charge for a grounded conducting plane.

Step 2. Calculating the Interaction Energy

The interaction energy of a charge with induced charges (or with its image) is given by one half the product of the charge times the potential at its location due to the image charge. (The factor Â½ is needed so that we do not count the â€œselfâ€interactionâ€ energy twice.) Thus
