â€ƒâ€ƒâ€¢ a charge â€“q located at (0, 0, a) (in the z > 0 region),
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€¢ a charge +q located at (0, 0, â€“a) (in the z < 0 region).

Because the dielectric constant is different on either side of the interface the usual Coulomb law must be modified by the boundary conditions at z = 0. In fact, the standard methodâ€ofâ€images solution (see, e.g., Jacksonâ€™s Classical Electrodynamics) tells us that when a point charge is located in one dielectric, the potential in that region is given by a â€œrealâ€ charge and an â€œimageâ€ charge (which mimics the effect of polarization induced at the boundary). Moreover, when a charge lies in the â€œotherâ€ medium the potential seen in our region of interest (here, z > 0) is â€œtransmittedâ€ in a way that is equivalent to having an effective charge of a modified strength.

Let us now â€œbuild upâ€ the field that the â€“q charge feels. (When computing a force by the method of images one must be careful to omit the spurious â€œselfâ€forceâ€ coming from the image corresponding to a given chargeâ€™s own field. However, when one is computing the force on a charge due to the induced surface â€œchargeâ€ â€“ which in the methodâ€ofâ€images solution appears as an image charge â€“ it is correct to include the interaction between the real charge and the other â€œimagesâ€.)

Step 1. Contribution from the dielectric interface induced by a charge in the same region

A point charge Q located in medium 1 (z > 0) produces a potential in that medium that is exactly reproduced by a â€œrealâ€ charge Q at the physical position and by an image charge Qâ‚áµ¢ placed at the mirror point (0, 0, â€“a) with
â€ƒâ€ƒQâ‚áµ¢ = Q Ã— ( (Îµâ‚ â€“ Îµâ‚‚)/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚) ).
In our problem the charge in medium 1 is â€“q. Thus there is an image (which is a mathematical tool giving the effect of the polarization of the interface) with
â€ƒâ€ƒ(â€“q)â‚áµ¢ = â€“q Â· ( (Îµâ‚ â€“ Îµâ‚‚)/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚) ).
This image is â€œlocatedâ€ at (0, 0, â€“a) and, when calculating forces on the real charge â€“q, its contribution must be included (even though it is â€œselfâ€likeâ€ the procedure is standard in such problems).

Step 2. Contribution from the charge in the other medium

The standard result (which may be derived by matching boundary conditions on the potential and displacement fields at z = 0) is that the field in medium 1 from a point charge Q in medium 2 is equivalent to that produced by a â€œtransmission imageâ€ located at the same position as the real charge, but with an â€œeffectiveâ€ charge
â€ƒâ€ƒQâ‚‚â‚œ = Q Ã— ( 2Îµâ‚/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚) ).
In our problem this charge is +q at (0, 0, â€“a), so its contribution in medium 1 is equivalent to having an effective charge
â€ƒâ€ƒqâ‚‚â‚œ = (2Îµâ‚/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚))Â·q,
also at (0, 0, â€“a).

Step 3. Combining the Contributions

Thus, as seen in medium 1 the effective charges (all â€œlocatedâ€ at (0,0,â€“a)) that act on our real charge â€“q at (0,0,a) are:
â€ƒâ€ƒ(i) Its own image:â€ƒâ€ƒâ€“q Â· ( (Îµâ‚ â€“ Îµâ‚‚)/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚) ),
â€ƒâ€ƒ(ii) The transmitted image for the charge +q:â€ƒâ€ƒ(2Îµâ‚q/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)).

â€ƒâ€ƒQ_eff = [2Îµâ‚q â€“ q (Îµâ‚ â€“ Îµâ‚‚)]/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚) 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= [(2Îµâ‚ â€“ Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)q]/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= ((Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)q)/(Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= q.
That is, surprisingly (or elegantly), the two contributions â€œcombineâ€ so that as far as the field in z > 0 is concerned the effective charge at the mirror point (0,0,â€“a) is exactly +q.

Step 4. Compute the Force

Now the real charge â€“q is at (0,0,a) while the effective charge q is at (0,0,â€“a). They lie along the z axis and are separated by a distance
â€ƒâ€ƒR = (a â€“ (â€“a)) = 2a.

â€ƒâ€ƒE_eff = (1/(4Ï€ Îµâ‚))Â·(q/(2a)Â²)Â·áº‘ 
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ= (1/(4Ï€ Îµâ‚))Â·(q/(4aÂ²))Â·áº‘

â€ƒâ€ƒF_ext = + (qÂ²/(16Ï€ Îµâ‚aÂ²)) áº‘.

\[

\]

We will show that one acceptable answer is to choose the radius of the sphere as
â€ƒâ€ƒa = d/8
so that when the sphere is grounded the two charges (located at x = â€“d and x = +d) â€œfeelâ€ no net force. Then if the same sphere is instead held at a constant potential V the extra field (which comes in as a monopole term) produces on each charge a force of magnitude

In the remainder of the answer we describe one way to arrive at these results.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Stepâ€byâ€step explanation

Let the two equal pointâ€“charges Q lie on the xâ€“axis at positions x = â€“d and x = +d. A sphere (a conductor) of radius a is centered at the origin. (We assume a < d so that the charges lie outside the sphere.) The problem is studied in two parts.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Part (a): Grounded sphere and zero net force

1. When the sphere is grounded the electric potential on its surface is forced to be zero. In the presence of an external point charge a â€œmethod of imagesâ€ is available. (Because our system is linear, if there are more than one external charges the solution is obtained by superposition.) In the case of one external charge Q at a distance râ‚€ from the center (with râ‚€ > a) the potential outside the sphere (r â‰¥ a) may be obtained by â€œreplacingâ€ the induced surface charge by an image charge
â€ƒâ€ƒQâ€² = â€“(a/râ‚€)Q
located at a point râ€² = (aÂ²/râ‚€) along the line joining the center with the charge. (One may consult a textbook for details.)

2. In our problem there are two charges (at â€“d and +d) so that by linearity the full potential for r â‰¥ a is the sum of the two â€œgroundâ€“sphereâ€ solutions. (That is, each external charge â€œseesâ€ its own image and the image due to the other charge.) Thus one may represent the effect of the conducting sphere by â€œplacingâ€ inside the sphere two image charges:
â€ƒâ€ƒFor the charge at x = +d, an image Qâ‚‚â€² = â€“(a/d)Q at x = aÂ²/d.
â€ƒâ€ƒFor the charge at x = â€“d, an image Qâ‚â€² = â€“(a/d)Q at x = â€“aÂ²/d.

3. Although the method of images is used to reproduce the correct potential for r â‰¥ a, the key point is that the electric field in the region of the two external charges is exactly that produced by the two â€œrealâ€ charges Q and the two image charges. (In computing the force on, say, the charge at x = +d one omits its own â€œselfâ€“fieldâ€.)

4. Now, choose one of the charges â€“ say the one at x = +d. Its full force is the sum of three contributions:
â€ƒâ€ƒ(a) The repulsion from the other real charge Q at x = â€“d. The separation is 2d so that by Coulombâ€™s law this gives a force of magnitude
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒFâ‚ = kQÂ²/(2d)Â² = kQÂ²/(4dÂ²)
directed to the right (i.e. away from the charge at â€“d).

â€ƒâ€ƒ(b) The force from the image charge Qâ‚â€² = â€“(a/d)Q at x = â€“aÂ²/d. Its separation from the charge at x = +d is
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚ = d + (aÂ²/d) = (dÂ² + aÂ²)/d.
Since the image is negative, the result is an attractive force of magnitude
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒFâ‚‚ = k Q [aQ/d] / Râ‚Â² = k a QÂ²/d / [(dÂ²+aÂ²)Â²/dÂ²] = k a QÂ² d/(dÂ²+aÂ²)Â²,
directed to the left (toward the negative xâ€“direction).

â€ƒâ€ƒ(c) The force from the image charge associated with the charge at +d itself, Qâ‚‚â€² = â€“(a/d)Q, which is located at x = aÂ²/d. Its separation from the external charge (at x = +d) is
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒRâ‚‚ = d â€“ (aÂ²/d) = (dÂ² â€“ aÂ²)/d.
Again, being negative, the force is attractive. Its magnitude is
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒFâ‚ƒ = k Q [aQ/d] / Râ‚‚Â² = k a QÂ²/d / [(dÂ²â€“aÂ²)Â²/dÂ²] = k a QÂ² d/(dÂ²â€“aÂ²)Â²,
directed to the left.

5. So the net force on the charge at x = +d is
â€ƒâ€ƒF_net = [Fâ‚ (to the right)] â€“ [Fâ‚‚ + Fâ‚ƒ (to the left)].
Setting F_net = 0 gives
â€ƒâ€ƒkQÂ²/(4dÂ²) = k a QÂ² d/(dÂ²+aÂ²)Â² + k a QÂ² d/(dÂ²â€“aÂ²)Â².
Canceling the common factor kQÂ² and multiplying through by dÂ² we obtain
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/4 = x [1/(1+xÂ²)Â² + 1/(1â€“xÂ²)Â²],
with the substitution x = a/d.

6. One now finds (by a short numerical search, say) that the solution of
â€ƒâ€ƒ1/4 = x [1/(1+xÂ²)Â² + 1/(1â€“xÂ²)Â²]
is
â€ƒâ€ƒx = 1/8.
That is, a/d = 1/8 or a = d/8.

Thus, if the sphere is grounded the induced charges produce exactly the right extra forces to cancel the repulsion between the two Qâ€™s provided that the sphere has radius

â€ƒâ€ƒa = d/8.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Part (b): Sphere at a potential V

When the sphere is held at zero potential the solution has the form we have just discussed. Now suppose the sphere is instead raised to a constant potential V (by â€œcharging it upâ€ ). Because the Laplace equation is linear one may write the solution as
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦_total = Î¦_grounded + Î¦_extra,
where Î¦_grounded is the potential we obtained with the sphere grounded (i.e. with zero potential on its surface) and Î¦_extra is a solution of Laplaceâ€™s equation which is chosen so that the total potential on the surface is V. (Also, one is free to add any constant since its gradient is zero.)

A very convenient choice is to take
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦_extra = V,
i.e. simply add a constant V everywhere. (Since the electric field is â€“âˆ‡Î¦, the extra constant does not produce any additional field and hence does not alter the induced â€œimageâ€chargesâ€ that produced our cancellation in part (a).) However, one must be a little careful: if we simply add a constant then though the potential on the sphere becomes V, the potential everywhere is raised by V but the electric field (and so the forces) remain exactly as in the grounded case.

But here the change in â€œcharge on the sphereâ€ (by charging it to potential V) is equivalent to adding a harmonic â€œmonopoleâ€ solution that does contribute to the electric field. In fact, an alternative (and indeed standard) way to produce a solution which is V on the sphere is to add the potential of a point charge at the origin that produces a â€œmonopoleâ€ potential. (In our problem since the sphere is a conductor the net field outside is in fact the superposition of the solution with a grounded sphere plus the potential due to a charge placed at the center whose value is adjusted so that the sphere attains the potential V.)

In practice one shows that the extra potential outside may be written as a monopole term:
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦_monopole = V (a/r).
One easily checks that on the surface (r = a) Î¦_monopole = V. (Notice that if V is constant, then its gradient is zero; however, the monopole term V(a/r) is not constant and produces an extra field.) Thus the complete potential is
â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¦_total = Î¦_grounded + V(a/r).

Since the force on any external charge is given by â€“qâˆ‡Î¦, the contribution coming from the added constant is nil; the only extra force comes from the monopole portion V(a/r). (This is the field that must be added in order to â€œcharge upâ€ the sphere, and which is responsible for the fact that the sphere now has extra net charge.) In particular, at the location of either external charge (which is at a distance r = d from the origin) the extra potential gives an electric field
â€ƒâ€ƒE_extra = â€“d/dr [V(a/r)] = V a/rÂ².
At r = d this is
â€ƒâ€ƒE_extra = V a/(dÂ²).
Since all the other contributions (the mutual repulsion of the two charges and the effect of the induced charges that was arranged to cancel it in part (a)) cancel when a = d/8, the net force on, say, the charge at x = +d is now entirely due to the monopole term:
â€ƒâ€ƒF = Q E_extra = Q [V a/(dÂ²)].
Using a = d/8 we obtain
â€ƒâ€ƒF = QV/(8d).

Note that the extra force is directed radially outward (i.e. away from the sphereâ€™s center) at x = +d (and radially inward at x = â€“d) so that in both cases the force pushes the charges away from the center.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Final Answer

Thus an acceptable answer is:

(a) In order that the forces on the two charges cancel when the sphere is grounded, one must have 
â€ƒâ€ƒa = d/8.

(b) When the sphere (of radius a = d/8) is instead held at a potential V, each charge Q experiences an extra force
â€ƒâ€ƒF = QV/(8d)
directed radially outward from the sphere.

\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to calculate the time required for the electronâ€™s orbit to decay from an initial radius râ‚€ (the Bohr radius) down to zero under the continuous loss of energy by radiation. We assume that during each revolution the energy loss is small compared to the total energy so that we may treat the orbit as nearly circular at all times.

We wish to know how the mutual capacitance between two thin metallic wires in the plane z = 0 changes when one fills the halfâ€space z < 0 with a dielectric of constant Îµ. In the original (allâ€vacuum) situation the capacitance is C. When the dielectric is introduced the space above the plane (z > 0) remains â€œvacuumâ€ (or air, with Îµ = 1) but the halfâ€space below (z < 0) has dielectric constant Îµ.

Step 1. Electrostatic Field Energy and Capacitance

The capacitance is determined by the relation Q = CV, where for a given charge distribution the voltage V between the wires is found by solving Poissonâ€™s equation in the space surrounding the wires. The energy stored is given by

â€ƒâ€ƒU = Â½ âˆ« (Îµâ‚€ Îµ(r)) |E(r)|Â² dÂ³r

where Îµ(r) = 1 in z > 0 and Îµ(r) = Îµ in z < 0.

If the electrodes (the wires) lie in the plane z = 0 then the electric field will â€œspreadâ€ both into z > 0 and into z < 0. In the original configuration these two halves both contribute equally (with Îµ = 1 everywhere). In the modified case one half of the space now has Îµ > 1. Roughly speaking the dielectric â€œhelpsâ€ to screen the fields from the charges, making the same charge arrangement create a lower potential difference. Since C = Q/V, lowering V for fixed Q increases the capacitance.

Step 2. Effective Permittivity Seen by Charge Sources on the Interface

A more quantitative way to see this is to recall that if a point charge is placed on the boundary separating two semiâ€infinite media with dielectric constants Îµâ‚ and Îµâ‚‚, the potential in the plane (or near the charge) behaves as if the medium had an effective dielectric constant

â€ƒâ€ƒÎµ_eff = (Îµâ‚ + Îµâ‚‚)/2.

In our problem Îµâ‚ = 1 (for z > 0) and Îµâ‚‚ = Îµ (for z < 0), so that

â€ƒâ€ƒÎµ_eff = (1 + Îµ)/2.

(One way to derive this is by noting that the method of images for a point charge placed exactly on the interface between two dielectrics shows that the potential in the plane due to the real charge and its image is, in SI units, equivalent to the usual Coulomb potential with a â€œrenormalizedâ€ Îµâ‚€. In twoâ€dimensional problems such as the one that gives a logarithmic potentialâ€”often used for long wiresâ€”the same effective average comes into play.)

Step 3. Relating the Effective Dielectric Constant to the Capacitance

In many geometries the capacitance is proportional to the permittivity of the medium. In our original allâ€“vacuum case the capacitance C is obtained for an effective permittivity of 1 (in units where the permittivity is measured relative to vacuum). With the lower halfâ€space replaced by a dielectric, the source charges â€œfeelâ€ an average permittivity Îµ_eff given by

â€ƒâ€ƒÎµ_eff = (1+Îµ)/2.

Thus, for fixed geometry the potential difference between conductors is lowered by the factor of 2/(1+Îµ) compared to the vacuum case. Since the capacitance is inversely proportional to the potential for a given amount of charge (C = Q/V), the capacitance is increased by a factor (1+Îµ)/2.

Step 4. Final Answer

Thus, the new mutual capacitance is

â€ƒâ€ƒC_new = ((1 + Îµ)/2) Â· C.

Finally, we box the answer as requested:

\[
\boxed{C_{\text{new}} = \frac{1+\varepsilon}{2}\, C.}
\]

We wish to â€œdesignâ€ a coaxial capacitor in such a way that the energyâ€density in the dielectric is constant. (By â€œenergy densityâ€ we mean the electromagnetic energy density stored in the dielectric.) That is, if the energy density is

â€ƒâ€ƒu(r) = Â½â€‰Îµâ‚€â€‰K(r)â€‰E(r)Â²â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(1)

we require that u(r) is independent of the radius r (so that there are no internal stresses associated with a nonuniform energy distribution).

In the usual cylindrical geometry the capacitor has an inner conductor at radius a and an outer conductor at radius b. In the present problem the dielectric constant is allowed to vary with r (i.e. it is â€œinhomogeneousâ€ and we write it as K(r)). When the capacitor is charged the voltage difference between the two conductors is V.

Let us proceed step by step.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. Use Gaussâ€™s law

For a cylindrical Gaussian surface of length L and radius r (with a â‰¤ r â‰¤ b) the free charge enclosed is Î»L where Î» is the charge per unit length on the inner conductor. Gaussâ€™s law (in integral form) then states

â€ƒâ€ƒâˆ®DÂ·da = D(r) (2Ï€rL) = Î»L,
â€ƒâ€ƒâ‡’â€ƒD(r) = Î»/(2Ï€r).

Thus we have

â€ƒâ€ƒÎµâ‚€â€‰K(r)â€‰E(r) = Î»/(2Ï€r)â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ(2)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ‡’â€ƒE(r) = Î»/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€â€‰K(r)â€‰r).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 2. Write the energy density

â€ƒâ€ƒu(r) = (1/2) Îµâ‚€â€‰K(r)â€‰E(r)Â²

â€ƒâ€ƒu(r) = Â½ Îµâ‚€ K(r) â‹… [Î»/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€ K(r) r)]Â²
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = Â½ Îµâ‚€ K(r) â‹… Î»Â²/(4Ï€Â² Îµâ‚€Â² K(r)Â² rÂ²)

â€ƒâ€ƒK(r) rÂ² = constant.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = Î»/(2Ï€ Îµâ‚€ C) â‹… [Â½ (bÂ² â€“ aÂ²)]

Thus, under the condition that the energy density is constant, the dielectric constant must vary as

In effect these two shells become one â€œcombined conductorâ€ which, together with the isolated intermediate shell (r = b) forms a twoâ€plate capacitor.

A physical picture of the situation is as follows. Writing

â€ƒâ€“ Let the one â€œbigâ€ conductor (the one formed by the union of the inner and outer shells) have total charge â€“Q_B. (This will be induced by any net charge Q_B placed on the intermediate shell so that overall charge is conserved.)

We wish to know whether a positive test charge can be held in stable equilibrium at the center of a cube formed by fixed positive charges q at its eight corners. Let us reason step by step.

Step 1. Symmetry of the Configuration  
The arrangement is perfectly symmetric. When a positive test charge is placed at the geometric center of the cube, the electric field contributions from the eight charges cancel out, so the net force is zero. Thus, the center is an equilibrium point.

Step 2. Nature of the Electrostatic Potential  
The potential at any point due to a point charge is given by V = kq/r. For a collection of fixed charges, the total potential satisfies Laplaceâ€™s equation (âˆ‡Â²V = 0) in free space (away from the fixed charges). A wellâ€known property of solutions to Laplaceâ€™s equation is that they cannot have a local minimum or maximum, only saddle points (or points of inflection) â€“ this is related to Earnshawâ€™s theorem.

Step 3. Stability Considerations  
Since the test charge is of the same sign as the fixed charges, any deviation from the center will break the perfect cancellation of forces. Although the center itself has a net force of zero, the second derivative (or curvature) of the potential will indicate instability (i.e., there will be directions in which the potential decreases as you move away). Thus, if the test charge is perturbed, it will experience a net force that pushes it away from the center. In this sense, the equilibrium is unstable.

Step 4. Potential Barrier or Tunneling  
The question specifically asks if, aside from quantum tunneling effects, there is any potential barrier that might â€œtrapâ€ the charge. In view of the analysis above, there is no confining potential well that could provide a barrier. At best, one might have hoped for a potential "bump" around the center but, due to the conditions set by Laplaceâ€™s equation, there is no local minimum where the charge could be stably suspended. Hence, from a classical point of view, there is no potential barrier maintaining the charge at the center.

Final Answer  
The positive charge at the center is at an unstable equilibrium (a saddle point) and cannot be suspended stably.

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 1. Singleâ€Dipole Radiation Pattern

An oscillating electric dipole that is polarized in the áº‘ direction radiates (in the far field) with an angular dependence proportional to

â€ƒâ€ƒI_single(Î¸,Ï†) âˆ sinÂ²Î¸.

In what follows we will neglect overall constant factors (that are the same for all our results).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

Since the dipoles are at different positions, the radiated fields add with phases that depend on the observation direction. In our case the seven dipoles are placed at
â€ƒâ€ƒx = â€“3Î»/2, â€“Î», â€“Î»/2, 0, +Î»/2, +Î», +3Î»/2.
Let the (wavenumber) be

â€ƒâ€ƒk = 2Ï€/Î».
  
An antenna located at x = d will have an extra phase factor exp[i k d sinÎ¸ cosÏ†] (because in the farâ€field the path difference is d sinÎ¸ cosÏ†). For our array we note that the spacing between adjacent elements is d = Î»/2. Therefore, if we introduce an index m running from â€“3 to 3 so that the mth element is at

â€ƒâ€ƒx = m(Î»/2),
  
then its phase factor is

â€ƒâ€ƒexp[i kÂ·(mÎ»/2) sinÎ¸ cosÏ†] = exp[i m (Ï€ sinÎ¸ cosÏ†)].

Thus the overall array factor (AF) is given by the sum

â€ƒâ€ƒAF(Î¸,Ï†) = âˆ‘â‚˜â‚Œâ‚‹â‚ƒÂ³ exp[i m (Ï€ sinÎ¸ cosÏ†)].

Since the elements run over m = â€“3, â€“2, â€¦, 2, 3 there are 7 terms. This sum is a finite geometric series. A wellâ€known formula for a sum of the type

â€ƒâ€ƒS = âˆ‘â‚˜â‚Œâ‚‹Nâ½Nâ¾ e^(i m Î´)
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = sin[(2N+1)Î´/2] / sin(Î´/2)
  
(apart from an unimportant overall phase) applies with N = 3 and Î´ = Ï€ sinÎ¸ cosÏ†. In other words,

â€ƒâ€ƒAF(Î¸,Ï†) = sin[(7Ï€/2) sinÎ¸ cosÏ†] / sin[(Ï€/2) sinÎ¸ cosÏ†].

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 3. Total Angular Distribution

Since the dipole radiation pattern gives a factor of sinÂ²Î¸ and the array factor adds its own modulation, the radiated intensity (up to an overall common multiplicative constant) is

â€ƒâ€ƒI(Î¸,Ï†) âˆ sinÂ²Î¸ Ã— [AF(Î¸,Ï†)]Â²  
â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒ = sinÂ²Î¸ Ã— [ sin((7Ï€/2) sinÎ¸ cosÏ†) / sin((Ï€/2) sinÎ¸ cosÏ†) ]Â².

This is the answer for part (a).

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Step 4. Comparison of Maximum Intensities

â€ƒâ€ƒÎ¸ = Ï€/2â€ƒâ€ƒ(with any Ï†)â€ƒâ€ƒ, with I_single,max âˆ 1.

For the array we must maximize the product sinÂ²Î¸ Â· |AF(Î¸,Ï†)|Â². It is useful to note that even though the dipole pattern is zero along the zâ€“axis (Î¸ = 0,Ï€), the array factor may be maximum in other directions. In our case, notice that the array sum

One may check (or argue physically) that this is the maximum achievable intensity. (For example, if we try Ï† = 0 so that cosÏ† = 1 then at Î¸ = Ï€/2 we have sinÎ¸ = 1 and the phase factor becomes Ï€, so that the numerator is sin(7Ï€/2) = â€“1 and the ratio becomes 1, leading to I = 1; this is far lower than the 49 we obtain at Ï† = Ï€/2.)

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

We wish to find the potential at the center of a dodecahedron when one of its faces is held at potential V while the other 11 faces are grounded (i.e. at 0). Although the geometry is not spherical, there is a very clever symmetry argument that immediately gives the answer.

Step 1. Note the symmetry of the dodecahedron

Although here the boundary condition is not â€œall faces the sameâ€, we can proceed by linearity and symmetry. Imagine solving the Laplace equation (Î”Ï† = 0) in the interior of the dodecahedron subject to the specified boundary conditions.

Step 2. Consider â€œbuilding upâ€ the solution by superposition

Let Ï†_i(r) be the solution (the potential everywhere inside) when only the iâ€‘th face is held at potential V and the other 11 faces are at 0. Because the dodecahedron is regular, whichever face we choose as the â€œactiveâ€ one, the potential at the center (r = 0) will be the same. Denote this value by A; that is, for each i
â€ƒâ€ƒÏ†_i(0) = A.

Now, notice that by superposition the solution for the case when all 12 faces are held at V (that is, Ï†_boundary = V everywhere on the faces) is simply the sum of the 12 solutions; that is,
â€ƒâ€ƒÏ†_all(0) = Ï†â‚(0) + Ï†â‚‚(0) + â€¦ + Ï†â‚â‚‚(0) = 12A.

Step 3. Use the uniqueness theorem

If every face of the dodecahedron is held at V, then by symmetry the solution inside is just the constant V (by the uniqueness theorem for Laplaceâ€™s equation in a region with Dirichlet boundary conditions); that is, Ï†_all(0) = V. Thus from the previous relation we obtain
â€ƒâ€ƒ12A = V,â€ƒorâ€ƒA = V/12.

Step 4. Conclusion

But A is just the potential at the center due to one face being at V while the other faces are grounded. Hence, the potential at the center in the original problem is V/12.

Final answer in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{\frac{V}{12}}
\]
